150455011.review:
I played this game with my significant other who looked exactly like the main character. The outfits, the aesthetic, the dreams. I looked like Krish. I have never been left more heartbroken after playing a game in my life. I turned around to see my s/o in tears after we finished. She was devastated that Florence did not end up with Krish. She continued to cry. I’m a fan of romances such as 500 days of Summer and La La Land, where sometimes life can get in the way of love. Perhaps love is something where people enter your life, change, and grow for the better. My only wish is that I wish they had an ending for Krish. This was a story about Florence, and about how others can rekindle a sweetness for life itself that can continue long after they are gone. The art in this game is brilliant. The comic book-style graphics and interfaces made for a unique storytelling environment – the puzzle piece mechanic for the conversation was amazing. I started to visualize conversations with my s/o as puzzle pieces and it actually made conversations smoother and more constructive.

---

	This is the significant other here: the one that looked like Florence. Yeah, this game made me sob really hard. The gameplay itself is very cute, intuitive, and enjoyable. I thought the colors, artwork, and transitions were very beautiful—and the story wrecked me. It’s bittersweet. It literally breaks your heart. But it squeezed my heart more because my significant other and I literally look like these characters. We have similar personalities: ambitious towards goals, artistic, emotional, etc. I really hope it's not a similar ending, but bittersweet might be in the future. Props to the creator, and I hope she’s healed from her relationship. I hope “Krish” has healed as well. I resonate with the story a bit too much, and as much as I want to recommend it to people, I also don’t want to. It might tug at your heart a bit more than you want. Every time I think about the game, I cry a little.

It took me about 40 mins to complete the story, and 15 more to get all achievements.
The game is cute, it has great art and music, but the story is pretty generic, and I kinda hate the message of the game.
Spoilers:
The story goes about 2 people who fall in love, both have their own hobbies, the guy plays music and the girl used to paint but not anymore; both motivate and support each other to follow their goals.
My issue is that the couple just gives up the second they have an argument, after the honeymoon phase is over, they just give up and get over it, they don't think a 6+ month relationship is worth saving after that, the game never gave the feeling that they were a toxic relationship or that they needed to get out of it because it wasn't good for them, they legit love and support each other, and for barely any reason they just give up in their relationship.

148947667.review:
Florence, a gaming masterpiece, offers an emotional and beautifully crafted experience that transcends the boundaries of the medium. This review aims to capture the essence of this remarkable game and why it is a must-play for anyone looking to embark on an extraordinary journey of self-discovery.

A Touching Love Story: 5/5
At its core, Florence is a love story that resonates on a profound level. It captures the nuances and emotions of a budding relationship between the titular character, Florence, and the enigmatic cellist, Krish. The story unfolds with breathtaking simplicity, touching upon the ups and downs of love, individuality, and compromise. It's an emotionally charged narrative that will tug at your heartstrings and leave a lasting impact.

Innovative Gameplay: 5/5
Florence's gameplay is an art form in itself. The game uses intuitive interactions to represent the stages of Florence and Krish's relationship, such as assembling puzzles, painting, and even navigating through conversations. These interactions seamlessly blend with the narrative, immersing you in Florence's world and emotions. The game's unique approach to storytelling sets it apart from traditional games.

Spectacular Art and Sound: 5/5
Visually, Florence is a masterpiece. The hand-drawn art style is vibrant, and the use of color is masterful, creating a visual tapestry that is both evocative and enchanting. The soundtrack, composed by Kevin Penkin, perfectly complements the story, with music that ebbs and flows with the emotional beats of the narrative. The combination of art and sound makes Florence a sensory delight.

Universal Themes: 5/5
Florence's themes of self-discovery, relationships, and the pursuit of one's passions are universally relatable. It speaks to the human experience, making it a game that transcends cultural and linguistic barriers. It's a reminder that we all have a Florence and Krish within us, searching for meaning and connection.

Short but Impactful: 4.5/5
Florence may be a relatively short game, but it's a testament to the idea that brevity can intensify impact. In just under an hour, it manages to create a more profound connection with its characters and story than many games achieve in ten times that duration. It's a beautifully concise experience that stays with you long after the credits roll.

In conclusion, Florence is a triumph in interactive storytelling, a game that touches the soul and evokes emotions like no other. With its exquisite art, innovative gameplay, and a powerful love story, it stands as a testament to the artistic potential of mobile gaming. It's a game that invites you to take a moment, to reflect on your own journey, and to appreciate the magic of connection and self-discovery. Florence is not just a game; it's a work of art that deserves a special place in your gaming library.
-

Amazing game! What makes it so amazing is as follows:
The music, Kevin Penkin did the music on this game and it is so amazing, it is that music in a game you can listen to outside of it and helps bring the game all together with the other elements.
The gameplay, while not challenging or incredibly fun, it does something I wish more games would do, where the gameplay itself ties in with the story so the player feels like what the gameplay is trying to convey. It is a difficult concept to convey but it is unique to this game.
The art and animations are beautiful, all well done and give the game a unique aesthetic.
The story is heartwarming and heart wrenching too, and I related to it very much and would recommend anyone to experience it.
Overall a game worth playing and getting. An amazing game, and honestly if I were to develop a game I wish it could be half the game this one is.

147643845.review:
i'll start by saying this made me cry - and i'm not even sure why. i guess i could resonate with her. if you don't, i find it unlikely that you'll enjoy this game, as it was the subtle relatability for me. that being said,

what i liked:
so, i did enjoy this! i do think the story had some depth if you've been there and add your personal experience to it. it speaks to you. if you don't get it, however, you don't and the game doesn't really try to convince you to (which is perfectly fine). for me, it was how it captured life losing its magic as you grow older. i also liked her relationship with her mom and [spoiler]how she was there for her at the end (not sure how that goes if you reject her calls during the game, i didn't)[/spoiler]. i loved some details such as the chat bubbles' puzzles getting easier as you get comfortable with the person. i liked the overall vibe and art style. i loved how it made you [spoiler]arrange your home when he moved in just to have you undo all of it, and you can notice your place will be much emptier than before he ever came around[/spoiler]. that hit really hard.

what i didn't like:
however, i would've liked to see her dealing with things losing their initial magic without discarding them, like [spoiler]with the boyfriend - which is fine! relationships end![/spoiler]. but the way it came across to me is that she only seemed happy with novelty and that applied to everything. it also never showed her having an art block or something, as if art solved everything and it came effortlessly all the time. i'm an artist, it doesn't work like that. even if she [spoiler]didn't touch it after childhood and did procrastinate throughout the entire game to get back into it[/spoiler], which is very realistic, once she started she never faltered and the game lost me there for a moment.

sidenote:
kinda irrelevant, but i was really thrown off by the immense credits list, i thought this was a one person game! as an aspiring game dev, knowing this was the work of so many people took away a bit of the personal touch i thought the game had. like, it was a group trying to sell an idea instead of a person trying to tell their own story. but hey, that's my personal take. also, objective complaint that will probably never be fixed but i'll throw this here anyway: the mouse commands are terrible on mac.

overall, i do recommend it if you feel like you can relate from the preview clips. if it doesn't spark anything on you, it might just not be for you and that's okay too.

147018457.review:
Este es uno de esos títulos que no se parece en nada a lo que suelo jugar, pero definitivamente fue una experiencia interesante.

Primero que nada, la estética de este juego es una maravilla. Los gráficos son sencillos pero hermosos, y la música es simplemente encantadora. Te sumerges en el mundo de Florence desde el principio.

La historia es bastante simple. Sigues la vida de Florence Yeoh, una joven que vive la rutina de la vida cotidiana hasta que conoce a Krish, y ahí es cuando comienza a ponerse interesante. La narrativa se desarrolla a través de pequeñas viñetas interactivas, donde debes resolver puzles simples para avanzar. Si esperas un juego lleno de acción y desafíos, este no es para ti. Es más como una novela gráfica interactiva.

Lo que realmente me atrapó de "Florence" es cómo aborda temas de la vida real, como el amor, las relaciones y la rutina diaria. Te hace sentir como si estuvieras viviendo esos momentos junto a Florence, y eso es lo que lo hace especial.

En cuanto a la duración, el juego es bastante corto, lo completé en una tarde, pero creo que eso es parte de su encanto. Es como leer un buen libro en una sola sentada. No hay mucho replay value, pero aún así, vale la pena echarle un vistazo si buscas algo diferente en el mundo de los videojuegos.

Un romance representado con un estilo visual precioso donde vas conectando con la pareja cada segundo que pasa. Y es que el juego no pretende contarte su historia a través de un texto, sino que mediante los colores vas entendiendo los sentimientos de la protagonista, como en este caso el amarillo, que destaca sobre el resto.

En cuanto al juego, sus mecánicas son sencillas y cómodas para que puedas disfrutar perfectamente. Se podría considerar como si estuvieras leyendo un cómic en el cual vas participando en varias ocasiones. 

Personalmente, recomiendo el juego, ya que tiene un ritmo relajado, con una historia que te emociona, un mensaje final positivo y con un dibujo realmente bonito. 146632399.review:
[h3]Florence is a game I played on my phone a long time ago, and I happened to see a sale so I bought it and played it again. I still think this game is very good, especially in terms of music.[/h3]
Florence Yeoh, an ordinary 25-year-old migrant worker, meets Krish one day by chance. Florence Yeoh was attracted to Krish's violin sound and developed a crush on him. An accident leads them to meet and know each other, and then to date and live together. The beginning of a relationship is always warm and wonderful, adding power and color to an otherwise boring life. Florence Yeoh and Krish did a lot of things together, encouraging each other to achieve a better self, a very romantic love.   But there will also be a day of argument, when the problem can not be resolved by words, the relationship cracks appear.  If at this time the two people's words become increasingly sharp, the words become more aggressive, the relationship will break down.  Florence Yeoh and Krish have a big fight, two people neither let anyone, as if the fight proves that they are right. This was a very wrong idea, so Florence Yeoh broke up with Krish.The feeling of falling out of love was very bad, and Florence Yeoh was immersed in the good memories of the past, until one day she picked up the paintbrush sent by Krish.Painting has always been Florence Yeoh's dream, and she seems to have found the original intention of painting.Florence Yeoh set up a website to sell her paintings, and she succeeded. Many people appreciated her paintings and even held an exhibition.  Florence Yeoh was no longer immersed in the sadness of the past.  She became better and stronger by relying on herself and the pursuit of her dream.Because of Krish, she had the drive to paint, but what kept going was her perseverance in her dreams.  Everyone should understand that their own success, their own happiness, their own carefree, is not given by others, but you have achieved.No one lives by anyone.  I have been wandering in the mud, there is someone like Krish to pull me out, let me feel the vitality of life and color, that time is simply my happiest days.   But there are always fights in a relationship, and in one of those fights, I said what I regret the most in my life.Those words let me cant pull back this relationship, I want to catch him, but I do not know how to cherish, do not understand that language is the sharpest knife, so I lost him. [b]I still feel happybout the good memories and regret what I said, but I don't get caught up in my own memories anymore.[/b][u]Fate is like this, he has left a strong color in my life, so I just need to feel happy for the good before, and then meet all kinds of people in life is enough. [/u]
[h3]Thank you.[/h3]

Florence I would call a short and cute graphic novel turned into a video game, and this move is validated by clever ways of both expressing character emotions in a way exclusive to it being a video game, and it's use of it's beautiful soundtrack. Florence has no voice acting, and any actual text is sparse, though through small minigames it's able to elevate it's story and characters.

The art is brilliant and gentle and the music flows perfectly alongside it.

The story is incredibly understated if that makes sense, with what it's trying to say but saying it here would spoil the story.

It's $2 on sale, it took me 40 minutes to complete. I honestly think you wouldn't get the full experience if you just watched a video playthrough.

146620937.review:
Florence is an emotionally charged interactive novel that takes players on a journey through the life of Florence. While the game has many strengths, including its beautiful art and atmospheric sound design, it falls short in a few areas.

One of the standout features of Florence is its art. The hand-drawn visuals are gorgeous, immersing players in a world of beauty and charm. The attention to detail adds depth to the narrative.

The sound design also deserves praise. It complements the story perfectly, enhancing the atmosphere and emotional impact. The soundtrack guides players through the ups and downs of Florence's life, making it an important part of the experience.

However, where Florence comes short is in its narrative. While it explores themes of love and self-discovery, the story feels somewhat cliché at times. It doesn't bring anything new in storytelling and relies on familiar tropes. Despite this, the relatable nature of Florence's journey kept me engaged.

Another aspect that has room for improvement is the mini-games. At the start, they are interesting and serve as a unique way to interact with the narrative. However, as the game progresses, they become repetitive and fail to evolve, bringing a sense of monotony.

Still, the overall journey is worth experiencing if you're looking for a heartfelt interactive novel.

Una maravilla es un juego que se basa en la integración de rompecabezas simples, que fusiona el arte visual, la música y la narrativa en una historia emotiva y conmovedora. 

La historia se trata de una joven y la monotonía de su rutina diaria hasta que un encuentro casual la lleva a descubrir el amor. 

Un juego que refleja la realidad de muchas personas y las varias etapas que esta conlleva, como tus amigos se alejan al pasar del tiempo, el no poder ser lo querías ser cuando grande por limitaciones, el amor, rupturas, y la capacidad de superar los desafíos y las adversidades, pero a medida que el juego avanza, aprendemos que con paciencia, perseverancia y apoyo mutuo, es posible superar obstáculos y seguir adelante.

144156070.review:
A game that is cute, and a game that is heartbreaking. A game that is sad, and a game that is hopeful. Florence is all of these things. It tells a simple but very real story with an art style almost out of a children's book (or one of those webcomics about love and anxiety you find on social media) and a truly beautiful orchestral soundtrack. I was pulled along through this game's twists and turns throughout the whole hour it took me to beat it, and it got me very emotional.

I love the different ways it portrays mundane everyday things, like trying to find the right words in a conversation or doing taxes, by turning them into fun little minigame puzzles that are not very difficult (many of them early on reminded me of a pop-up book), but keep you engaged with Florence's life, and helping to tell the story in easy to understand way without needing any actual words!

If there's only one problem I have about this game, is the segments where you scroll down the page of a comic. Dragging the paper with my mouse feels clunky, and scrolling with the scroll wheel is too sensitive and moves too quickly. It's just the least imaginative form of storytelling in this game, it's like reading a Webtoon. But this is the only bad thing I have to say about the entire game, and it's just a tiny nitpick, so that should tell you how brilliant the rest of it is!

143980494.review:
Introduction:

In the symphony of interactive experiences, "Florence" emerges as a virtuoso composition, orchestrating the delicate nuances of human emotions through the lens of a meticulously designed game. Mounting itself as a beacon of artistic elegance, "Florence" crafts a narrative ballet that unfurls the complexities of love and self-discovery with poignant grace. This review embarks on an analytical odyssey, delving into the multifaceted layers that constitute the ethereal tapestry of "Florence."

Artistic Visual Language:

From the very first brushstroke, "Florence" declares its artistic intent with fervent confidence. The minimalist visual style transcends mere aesthetics, becoming a language that reverberates with the resonance of emotion. Employing a subdued color palette and charmingly abstracted characters, the game channels the influence of graphic novels, fostering a sense of engagement akin to a page-turning novella.

The seamless integration of visual elements with the interactive medium imparts a tangible immediacy to Florence's world. Each delicate gesture, each whimsical flourish speaks volumes, crafting a nonverbal narrative that resonates beyond the screen. The graphical metamorphosis paralleling the ebb and flow of the protagonist's emotions is a testament to the developers' dedication to visual storytelling, echoing the cinematic language of auteurs.

Audio Sculpting and Subtle Nuances:

"Florence" employs an auditory symphony that delicately entwines with the gameplay, elevating the emotional cadence. Kevin Penkin's original score, akin to an aural caress, navigates the player's emotional voyage with deft precision. The minimalist arrangement, interwoven with motifs that mirror Florence's emotional journey, seamlessly underscores the narrative beats.

Sound effects echo with a narrative purpose, intricately choreographed to mirror the characters' interactions and feelings. The rustling of paper, the chime of a phone notification, the subtle crescendos of a piano - each auditory element is a deliberate brushstroke on the canvas of player experience.

Narrative as an Interactive Dance:

The narrative architecture of "Florence" diverges from conventional storytelling paradigms, weaving an intimate tale of love, aspirations, and self-actualization. The game's core conceit rests in the symbiotic relationship between its interactivity and narrative, converging to mold an emotionally charged odyssey. The player isn't merely an observer but an active participant, their engagement mirrored in the protagonist's emotional journey.

The narrative dissects the eponymous character's life with a surgeon's precision, each interaction dissecting layers of personality and personal evolution. By deconstructing the mundane aspects of life – the rise and fall of relationships, professional struggles, familial dynamics – "Florence" subverts the banal and renders it extraordinary. This deconstructionist approach, akin to a literary deconstruction, peels away the veneer of routine to unveil the raw core of humanity.

Interactive Choreography and Pacing:

The balletic choreography at the heart of "Florence" elicits parallels with the rhythm games genre. However, this endeavor ascends beyond the confines of mere mechanics, employing gameplay as an extension of emotional expression. The narrative pacing is intricately calibrated, mirroring the oscillations of real-life interactions. Tapping into the minutiae of routine, "Florence" transforms the act of brushing teeth, folding laundry, and sharing conversations into an interactive ballet that celebrates the intricacies of human connection.

Conclusion:

In a medium often commoditized by frenetic action and grandiose narratives, "Florence" emerges as a transcendent magnum opus, seamlessly intertwining interactivity, artistry, and storytelling. It elevates the gaming sphere, redefining the boundaries of emotive engagement. Through its meticulously curated aesthetic, harmonious auditory design, and profound narrative sensibilities, "Florence" weaves an emotional tapestry that invites players to explore the symphony of everyday existence. As a paragon of interactive art, "Florence" beckons the gaming community to embrace the power of nuanced emotional storytelling, transcending the boundaries of traditional entertainment into the realm of soul-stirring experiences.

143177121.review:
To be fully honest, the game was a tad dissapointing for me personally... Maybe because I expected some kind of deeper message or being offered mature answers ... But it did not deliver it. Still, it was worth the time and the ideas for the puzzles were neat - it made you feel like you are going through the stages together with the characters. But story´wise, It only once again recycled the idea that "even good love ends if you are not your own person first" - which is not always true, sometimes the other person can teach you to be more your self. And if it is a supportive partner, they will make you blossom - if it is the right person. And vice versa. 
 (maybe if they portrayed some really drastic imbalance/incompatibility, the end would feel less forced and less petty... Instead, they made it seem like completely normal things inside a relationship - such as differences in opinions, some fights, different goals - cannot be worked on together and will inevitably lead to a bitter scarring end. It was hinted at Florence suppressing self from start - but it did not feel like something that she could not have worked on, once noticed... If the relationship started being abusive, maybe the message would also be more focused, more clear... - but the guy was just immature - also something that he could work on. So instead of feeling healed by the game after my own situationship trauma -  it made me feel unexpected dread O __ O ).

Work cannot replace a missing relationship, but it can distract you from the pain or help you channel the pain into useful thing. But that by it self is not enough to be healed after breakup trauma. 
Nevertheless, the game is still very nice and I would recommend it- it was worth the buy at discount price,  was entertaining and smart in the way it meshed together the game mechanics, comics style of storytelling and portrayal of stages of the relationship. The music stood out from the start, Kevin Penkin was a very nice (and unexpected) surprise!

142516485.review:
I'm going to give this game a reluctant thumb up, even though I didn't wholly enjoy it. What gives?

"In Florence, the player follows the story of 25-year-old Florence Yeoh as she lives her daily routine and meets Krish, a cellist she sees in the park. The game features little written dialogue and tells Florence's story through a series of brief chapters. Puzzles are used to reinforce pieces of Florence's life as players progress through her story.

Lead designer Ken Wong wanted to create games that eschewed violence and was inspired by his work on Monument Valley to have a more narrative-focused experience that included puzzles. The game received critical acclaim that praised the game's art-style, music, and narrative structure, but received some criticism for its ending."

Well, first of all, the puzzles in this game are sweet and simple, but more than that I admire the way they were intertwined with the story. They served as interesting narrative devices and helped you experience the childlike creativity when putting colourful shapes on paper, the way it gets easier to talk to someone with time or how to decorate a shared space when there's suddenly someone new in your home. The way the balance shifts in arguments (in this game, literally), how routine catches up with people and the process of letting go.

The art was very sweet and simplistic; in its details you can see how this is a beloved project by its developers. It is well-narrated and definitely on the better side of virtual novel games.

I think the game will give you as much as you are willing to think about it and put your own two cents on top of the story. While playing the game, I could definitely enjoy and reflect on it and strive for a full achievement game play. So I guess it's also pretty cool for achievement hunters. (You can go back to specific chapters, making it easy to complete)

I did not enjoy the game after all of this praise, because looking back, the story is very cliché. Meet cute between boy and girl and life plays out. It is not very unique in these aspects, but more of a feel-good (and bad) slice of life game. I would've liked the story a little bit differently, but that is entirely subjective. The people behind this game wanted to tell a specific story and they achieved that and baked a simple delicious dessert. But I guess these kind of games are just not my cup of tea.

I would've enjoyed a different portrayal in relationships, puzzles that don't give you the feeling of a fight between two people, but cooperation and problem-solving. It is a sad and stereotypical route to take: people getting bored of each other very soon after dating, fighting and growing distant. I would've loved a twist on this! Where are my healthy relationships of two people that actually like each other? People growing because of their love to their partner. Partners that don't give in to the cliché of being bored of each other, but finding excitement themselves.
But those are very high expectations fueled by wishful thinking! And I understand that this is not the story they wanted to tell: there are at least as many stories as people in this world.

So, after all, I can recommend this game. If you are hesitant, wait for a sale perhaps. But if you love the idea of this game and are prepared to put your head casually into it, go off. It is quite enjoyable and has nice symbolistic value. My criticism could be even taken as a plus, because the game enabled me to reflect on different relationship dynamics, which is the selling point of this game for me.

142193828.review:
Amazing visual storytelling, but the most generic, boring plot imaginable.

Florence is basically a 2D animation short film with the occasional interactive element, that mostly fits the narrative. The visual storytelling and representation of themes and motives is really well done. I particularly liked how a dialogue bubbles are jigsaw puzzles that get easier to solve, the more you know someone. Not all the interactions are great, the game constantly switches up horizontal and vertical scrolling and sometimes you don't scroll at all. Sometimes I had no idea what to do, but the game solved itself anyway. I would have liked more gameplay elements that reinforce what the characters are going through. The whole thing can be completed in 30 minutes, no idea how people spend hours with this game.

Now the main issue is, this is the most generic, unoriginal story about a couple basically ever. Unfortunately, once you realize the story is as deep as a puddle, it becomes incredibly boring too. The visuals and animations are lovely, but when there is zero substance behind anything, I don't see any point in learning about the protagonist. The last half of the "game" turns into a total slog. 

I am sorry, just watch any decent A24 movie, the stories in those films about relationships are infinitely more compelling than this cliché dump. I would say, the game paints a really unhealthy and backwards picture of relationships and self-fulfillment. The story basically says that the honeymoon phase is the only good part of a relationship and once it becomes the norm, it's no longer worthwhile. And then randomly picking up a hobby that you did as 6 year old is totally going to fill your life with wonder and creativity, even though you have zero practical skills in the field. This was probably written by a teenager or someone with a really immature look on life. Truth is, life is messy, work is hard, social circles are not easy, you can't just view things through a rose colored glass. 

The more I think about this the more I dislike this story. It's embarrassing that this has received any awards, especially a Bafta.

142140856.review:
[h1]TLDR[/h1]
Florence is like a tiny version of Life is strange and it comes with beautiful hand drawn art and the music is beautiful too!  Florence is a short product with a [u]BIG[/u] message! 

[h1]Non-TLDR[/h1]
Florence (Flo in short) is developed by Mountains and published by Annapurna Interactive. The PC version was released on Feb 13 2020. It is also On: iPhone/iPad, Switch. As of this writing, Metacritic (https://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/florence) shows:
[list]
    [*]An average user score of 6.7 from 44 ratings
[/list]

If you love visual novels or story rich games, should you try this? Definitely a yes.

[h1]Controls, Audio, Visuals, Story[/h1]
Visuals: Simple and beautiful. It looks like its hand drawn. +1 to the visual team.

Audio: The music in this game is beautiful. +1 to the audio team.

Controls: mouse clicks +1 to the devs. I will elaborate more under mechanics.

Story: On the surface, this may seem insignificant, obviously the story focuses on the main protagonist's life [u]but[/u] it also tries to cover some life/social issues in a very small format. Good work story telling team. + 1 to the writing team

[h1]Mechanics[/h1]
Flo comes with a chapter saving system! it has confirmation button to move to the next screen! and you can also "skip" end credits!

Many game studios overlook at this sort of design choices and over the time, i find myself repeating the same thing over and over again whenever i submit my writing on visual novel games. Emphasizing how important it is to have these because it affects replay-ability. and Flo delivered it. From a small game studio that nobody has heard of. so kudos to the devs.

Throughout the game, Flo has small, simple puzzles. It does not infuriate you and does not break the immersion. It lets you enjoy Florence's day to day activities.

The best part of the game? is the controls. just a simple mouse to click and drag. no finger entanglement crap going on here. I can see the devs really tried to deliver a "seems less" gaming experience with all this choice of design. Great work! 


[h1]My personal thoughts/My Summary[/h1]
Florence to me is like a tiny version of Life is strange. The hand art is amazing and coupled with the amazing music, you'll feel relaxed and you'll find yourself progressing through florence's daily day to day easily. It is a very short game but that doesnt mean it doesnt offer much. Remember i said its like a tiny version of Life is strange? It has a "slice of life" experience for you as you go through Florence's journey. on friendship. on love. about dreams/choices and "adulthood".
Its simple, beautiful, gets the message across. 

Like i said in the past, small game studio should focus on the product on small scale and deliver a good quality/gaming experience and Florence is a great example to take note of! 
Thank you mountains and Annapurna Interactive for this great product!


So, on the scale of 0 - 10, my personal rating for Florence is an [b]AMAZING[/b] 7/10.
I am going to start replying text messages with Heart emojis only. lol

141698287.review:
Florence is a short point and click puzzle game by Annapurna Interactive. This game can make you feel amazed about how the mechanics alone can bring you into an atmosphere of happiness.

You play as Florence Yeoh, a adult  woman who works as an accountant. Of course, with the short time provided by this game, the selling point of this game is the gameplay and story. The gameplay will show you how every day Florence passes its time, from waking up to the end of the day. You will play as yourself in this game, following all her routines like work, liking social media posts etc.

The story will focus on how bored Florence is with her life. She had no friends, and the only one she called was her mother. Every day feels the same way until she meets someone in the park. That person played a beautiful melody on his cello. That day would start a new life for Florence Yeoh because now she has a boyfriend.

There are no major flaws in this game, expect short gameplay. I just finished the game for 1 hour and all achievements are done. Playing this again can bring back the enchanting feel again. That's obvious since it's a linear story game.

Even though the gameplay is short, this game offers many chapters that you can play and each chapter has its own unique gameplay. The story pacing is impeccable and I could feel the emotions going through the gameplay itself, a truly amazing experience.

I think it's worth your money, even if you've never played a point and click game before. This game is not difficult at all and I think everyone can enjoy it. Once again I recommend this game to anyone who is tired of all the AAA games that have the same concept and wants to experience something better.

141466859.review:
[h2] 𝐅𝐥𝐨𝐫𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐞, 𝐥𝐨𝐯𝐞 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐚 𝐥𝐢𝐟𝐞 𝐥𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐨𝐧 𝐭𝐨 𝐛𝐞 𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧𝐞𝐝. [/h2]

In the game, you laugh, cry, get stressed, and when you are tired of the daily bad news, you can take refuge in it for a short time. Of course, this good feeling does not last long, but for these few minutes, your mind will be filled with positive energy.

The game has everything together. As much as it depicts the beauties of love in the most pleasant way possible, it also talks about problems. A real life that may be a little far from the current reality, but it has sweet and difficult moments that many of us may experience in every second.

Florence narrates the story of a girl who is drowned in everyday life. He goes to work every day, looks at his Instagram from time to time, watches TV, and sometimes talks to his mother on the phone. However, an incident gives a different color to his life.

We see very few writings in the game and there is no dialogue at all. Instead, the creator has used music, coloring and puzzles to narrate his creation. From the very beginning, when you enter the menu, the game will enchant you with its music, and this feeling will be maintained until the end.

Depending on what happens, you hear a different piece of music and these pieces show parts of the characters' emotions. Graphics have the same task in the first place. The change of colors and the intelligent movement of a certain spectrum, well depict the current world of Florence and the atmosphere that dominates her life at every moment.

Florence does not have an engaging gameplay, the game was presented as an interactive story from the very beginning, and therefore, like other titles of this genre, all you have to do is a few simple clicks or changing some objects.

However, these small movements are not only for the interaction of the player with the game, and the developer has put a part of the story of the title on them. In Florence, everything is at the service of the story, and the creator showed the emotions of his world in ways different from what we have known so far.

In the end Florence is worth a try. A pleasant and short experience that can make you feel better.

141118641.review:
A wonderful experience with a rollercoaster of emotions, Florence plays like an interactive graphic novel, and takes you through some key moments in the life of its titular character.

The gameplay is how all interactive graphic novels should play. Each interaction makes sense for the scene, and nothing goes on so long as to overstay it’s welcome. I particularly enjoyed the conversations in the game, where the gameplay is essentially you piecing together a conversation as you get to know someone, with the puzzles having fewer pieces as the conversation goes on, implying that it’s less difficult to think of what to say and the conversation flows more easily. Similarly when an argument starts, the pieces become sharper, adding to the tone.

Overall, the gameplay was perfect for the type of game. 

The sound design was also perfect, and even after the game completed I kept it open to listen to one particular piece which was just so beautiful (and in a perfect loop for anyone else like me just wants to chill to it for a while). It really added to the story and the emotions in certain scenes.


In terms of the story, it’s on the shorter side, with a full play through taking around 30-40 minutes. Despite that, it’s packed with a rollercoaster of emotions, and really was a perfect length to tell the story it did. I only mention the length in case it influences someone’s decision on what price point is worth it. 

A cleanup of achievements afterwards doesn’t take long, for anyone interested in that - chapter select lets you jump straight to the scene with the achievement you missed and you can fly through them quickly and just enjoy the story without worrying on your first play through. That’s how I’d recommend to play anyway.


Overall, I’d 100% recommend this experience to anyone who is looking for a short but impactful story.

141035931.review:
30-40 minute visual novel (70 if you want all the achievements)

It's a short and sweet interactive story, there are minigames/puzzles to get through the story - they're all pretty fun, and the art is (as it usually is with visual novels) very pretty 
You don't get any different endings or many choices, but it does tell it's story very well

It slowed my computer pretty severely when it was on though, so I wouldn't recommend playing it with something else open on the side :D

The game's about finding love, rediscovering your passions and letting go
No words are spoken, but a lot of things are said

One of my favorite things in the game was the minigame where you put together speech bubbles, and how it gets easier the more familiar you are with a person, and how it gets sharper the more you're mad

The music was also pretty good! 

It's not like something I'd aggressively recommend, but like, if you like visual novels, buy it when it's on sale and have yourself a nice little hour playing it.

It goes very nicely with hot chocolate

Florence es una "aventura gráfica" lineal donde reviviremos los pasos de la protagonista en su monótona vida de mujer de 25 años. Su vida da un giro al conocer a su nueva pareja, y se nos muestra lo que es la vida. Situaciones cotidianas que hay que vivir, veces que se está arriba y veces que se está abajo, y como la vida siempre nos depara cambios inesperados.

La narrativa y el aspecto visual son muy buenos, sin apenas texto se siente cada una de las emociones de los personajes. Sin embargo, el sistema de "juego" es ausente. Resolver minijuegos para que la historia avance. Ninguna de las decisiones que tomamos cambian nada de lo que depara en el futuro a Florence, y eso hace que sea como ver una serie animada.

The story uses cleverly thought out forms of visual interaction which mirror the effect or feeling of the interaction without much use of language (apart from location names or limited telephone interactions where language is employed). 138628431.review:
Fantastic and emotional short game that guides you through the story of Florence and her steps during a love relationship, giving not only a very mature message but also a way to heal or reflect if you have been through her steps. I have to admit it made me very emotional and a bit tearful, in the good way by the end.

The art style is simple and plays a lot and very cleverly with colors and greyscales to convey the protagonist's emotions, while you have a beautiful OST to enjoy deeper each chapter. The game is simple but very well designed, you have a few puzzles and a few clicking interations, as well as some drags; nothing overcomplicated. You might think that the lack of dialogue or voice over is a downvote, but it isn't, there's no need for it as you can understand what the story is telling you. 

Game is beatable by 1h, so it's great for when you feel too overwhelmed with anything and need a small and short game, or you don't have enough time to play o need a simple one. Extra points to this game as you'll get the Official OST when buying it!


=== ⭐ Recommended?  ===
Totally worth it! 100% recommended!

This was such a sweet and emotional game about life itself.  I personally really love the story being told through the game rather than direct storytelling. One of my favourite examples of slight gameplay clues telling the story was the speech bubbles. In chapter 5 when florance has dates with krish. As dates go on, her speech bubble puzzles get easier and it shows that she found it easier to talk to him. 137767051.review: Short, beautiful game. It might make you cry if you just recently went through a breakup (or in the midst of getting over someone).

137754713.review:
Florence is lovely in story, art, and music. It captivates you into a completely different world and a person’s life and sometimes you just need to get away from your own life to jump into someone else’s and learn something. 

It may not look like it at first glance, but the story is original and raw. It’s not common to see breakups reflected in a positive light like it is in Florence. I love that it lets you engage in all the negativity, the heartbreak, the pain and the healing process to be able to process and understand the positivity of it. No, not everyone is going to become extremely successful in an infamously non-lucrative field, and that wasn’t the point of the story at all. The point is that her relationship, despite being broken, changed her for the better. It taught her to self-reflect, learn about herself, take risks, and to love herself enough to gather the courage to do something she loves. It is often underestimated how these little choices can change your life and I love that this is demonstrated through a heartbreak she had. A relationship and heartbreak can leave you loving yourself more and have a stronger sense of who you are. That’s the lesson here. 

Through her investing in herself, she was able to get over her heartbreak. She looks at a photo of them in the end, when her life is going so well that she built all by herself, and she smiles. She smiles because she learned to move on through loving herself. Not enough people do that. 

The game is very short, under an hour, but it’s concise and it hits all the points it was trying to make. It told the story it needed to. It didn’t have to break down every single detail and situation. I actually liked how vague it can be because it leaves you to consider other lives, feelings, and thoughts on your own. You don’t need to get bogged down in details and get stuck in the mindset of “X is mad because Y therefore do not do Y.” People and life are a lot more complex than that. 

This is the longest review I’ve ever written for a game and the most thought I’ve ever put into a game and it’s only 45 minutes long. It’s impactful, go play it if it’s your kind of thing. 

I look forward to seeing what else the devs do!

Not recommended for kids.
Not recommended for young teens.
Highly recommended for adults. It's very relatable. It's also short, easy to play if you have 30~45 minutes to spare.

This game is almost an interactive comic strip that tells the story of Florence. It's touching. It's heartfelt. It's a slice of life. It may bring tears to your eyes.

Besides the simple but well thought hand-drawn graphics, the background music creates the exact mood to make you feel the feelings of the characters.

Additionally, some of the feelings can actually be felt through the gameplay itself. I'm not going into too much detail, because you should experience it yourself.

The game plays fine either with a gamepad or with a mouse or with touch screen. It's also available on mobile, but the PC version has a gallery of early art and concepts (which you should only view AFTER completing the story).

135452067.review: [h1]When you write a story, you tell it through the mirroring lens of a character(s) of whom thousands upon thousands more can identify through, relate to, and [i]feel deeply[/i] with.[/h1]  [list][/list] Think about the typical romantic story, or even just your own. [b]Florence[/b] tells that story, in a very relatable way. The weals and woes of love--the warm memories of honeymoons and the cold trials of reality in settling down. And the aftermath. [list][/list] People are prone to tell the story of love through the wishful wisps of it's beginning, the exciting impetus of the connecting, and the blissful permanence when all is just [i]perfect[/i]. Or, the [b][i]im[/i][/b]permanence of it, and what we dread to come. [list][/list] Love is a challenging contract that always comes with a termination date of unknown terms. We just don't know when it happens, or even what happens, just like everything else. It's why you learn to appreciate the memories that comes with it, and how to appreciate it's momentary visit on your doorstep. It's also about what happens after. [list][/list] [b][u]Florence[/u][/b][u] is a story about love and life.[/u] [list][/list]Feel free to get it while it's on sale, and set aside less than only just 2 hours for a great introspective indulgence.

135278458.review: Presented with a great art style, Florence tells one of the fundamental stories of life--growing up, falling in love, and all the things that come with that--with almost no dialogue at all. It's heavily story driven with minimal point-and-click gameplay. Some of the gameplay sections could be described as puzzle like, but nothing is challenging. Limited and simple though this gameplay is, it is cleverly implemented at various points, such as a section where an argument is taking place and you must fill the speech bubble with various shapes. These shapes start as simple puzzle pieces, but as the conversation progresses to argument, the pieces become jagged and sharp and the speed increases. I enjoyed reflecting on how the gameplay drove home the narrative in place of dialogue. If you like short, artsy, narrative driven games, I recommend it. It can be beaten in under an hour, but it's clear this was a passion project for the small dev team. Great score too.

135249109.review:
I wanted to give this game a nuanced review as the most critical reviews of this game's storylines are far from being actually true or close to what happens. I never really review games but I saw a lot of misinterpretation for this game.

If you're worried this game tells you to throw away valuable relationships just because you want to follow your dreams, don't worry. Because it doesn't tell you that. This game is about what it means to progress through life and how even your failures, including failed relationships, can become a valuable resource that helps you grow as an individual. It also demonstrates a very important piece of life advice: The circumstances in your life are always bound to change, and the more you grow, the more you outgrow certain things. Or you may grow into new things. 

The game is short but the message the game sends is quite strong. Whether it is worth five dollars, maybe I would just wait until it's on sale because of the length and simple mechanics. Great art style, but the game itself feel more suited for mobile platforms (I believe this is on the app store). Watch a YouTuber play through it if you feel unsure. But what the game is commonly critiqued for isn't fair, and I strongly recommend exploring the story for yourself to make your own judgement.

135018234.review:
///Spoilers del juego evidentemente///

Sin duda Florence es una experiencia sumamente memorable, todos los aspectos del juego están muy bien pensados y se complementan y resultan impactantes, la historia de Florence y Krish es una bella historia que lamentablemente tiene un final, utiliza ocurrencias de Ken Wong el creador de Florence y sabe implementar muy bien sus ideas sin llegar a plasmarse a si mismo en la obre, el quería un final donde hubiera un reencuentro pero sabia que eso no era lo que Florence quería, algo que tiene una gran importancia ya que después de haber dejado ir al amor de su vida logra enfocarse en si misma, algo que aunque pudo haber hecho durante la relación ya que recibió apoyo de Krish su pareja en ese entonces no le dio realmente una gran importancia hasta terminar con la relación, y en su búsqueda de motivación encontró las acuarelas (o pinturas) que Krish le había regalado encontrando nuevamente su pasión.

Dejando un poco de lado la narrativa, el gameplay es simple, estaba pensado para lanzarse en dispositivos móviles, Ken menciono que no buscaba crear mecánicas desafiantes sino que encajaran con la historia y las emociones que buscaba transmitir y es algo que se hizo muy bien con este juego, un detalle por ejemplo es que cuando armas globos de texto en la primera cita, estos empiezan teniendo muchas piezas pero a medida que avanza la cita comienzan a haber menos piezas, es un detalle bastante sutil que apoya mucho a tu relación con la historia, lo mismo pasa cuando pelean, sientes la tensión y la presión de Florence durante el calor del debate, escenas cómo la mudanza resultan tristes.

Para finalizar quiero destacar que si has leído esto sin haber jugado el juego, igualmente vale la pena jugarlo por tu cuenta, Florence hace algo muy bien, y es que se sienta personal al jugarlo, saludos consumidores de Steam, me despido.

134655568.review:
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Factor[/th]
        [th]Rating[/th]
	[th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Gameplay Loop[/td]
        [td]4[/td]
	[td]You've likely heard of this game because of the "puzzle mechanic" haven't you? If you don't know what it is, play it without knowing! I talk about it in the next section, if you're already familiar. Aside from that, there's simple gameplay mechanics the game uses to tell its sweet and simple story. I do think they could've been slightly more creative within the same mechanics itself, and I elaborate it later - but I overall loved the things they ended up doing. It's a VERY short game, I'd be surprised if someone doesn't finish it in one sitting. It has some unique ideas on how it tells it's simple story through the interactive medium - and if you're someone who's into that, you should certainly give it a shot.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Narrative[/td]
        [td]6[/td]
	[td]The story is as simple as they come. And that's not a bad thing at all. It follows [spoiler]the story of Florence through her monotonous life, which is broken when she meets someone. We follow wholesome moments as both of them grow as individuals, grow as a couple, and eventually grow apart. It's a simple premise, made interesting by how it uses mechanics to convey certain ideas. My favourite example is when you both start talking, the puzzles that comprise the dialogue bubbles are more complex and harder, but as the conversation eases up, so do the puzzles. Such a simple yet fantastic way of conveying that! It does get overused slightly IMO and wish they'd just gone with the "less is more" rule on that one, using it only on the imp bits. My main issue is that the story doesn't seem to have a strong takeaway or something in its ending that hits you with something impactful. Like okay, they break up and she's living alone now, so what? What else could they have done? Well, there's this bit when he's moving in with you where you're allowed to take some stuff off your shelves to make space for his stuff. And then when you break up it comes back as you clear those shelves. I was VERY much expecting this to come into play in the ending, because a normal player would 100% forget to clear at least ONE of the guy's items, right? And then Florence spots it, and just longingly thinks back on her great experience and how it changed her for the better, and how people in your life will always leave traces of themselves in your life, however temporary. Would've been such an amazing bit to end in, and factor in its own gameplay mechanics for it. Another thing I wished they'd done was do away with all "text". There was no dialogue, which is great - but it didn't need chapters or text to show things either. Would've been so unique to have a game tell its story without the use of any words at all.[/spoiler] So yeah, I've a lot of appreciation for what this game does, but little changes here and there could've elevated it to another level![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Visuals[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
	[td]The game's obviously pretty aff. Has a very distinct, simple art style.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Mechanics[/td]
        [td]5[/td]
	[td]I enjoyed the puzzle mechanic ofc, which seems to be the first thing people talk about when speaking of the game as well. Aside from that, it was simple stuff like clicking, scrolling, dragging and dropping. But again, it's just as much about how you use it eg. basic minigames to establish monotony in her life. Like how I said the cupboard arranging bit could've been used to hit home a message so strongly![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Challenge[/td]
        [td]4[/td]
	[td]There isn't much of a challenge the game offers, and I don't mean just in terms of "video game challenge" - but simply understanding/interpreting its themes and ideas. It's a pretty straightforward story. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Variety[/td]
        [td]5[/td]
	[td]Given the length, the game sure tries to fit in some variety in conveying its themes and ideas. I do think they tend to get repetitive after a while and wish they'd put in a couple more inventive ideas in there. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Mapping[/td]
        [td]-[/td]
	[td]-[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Sound[/td]
        [td]6[/td]
	[td]The music is pleasant and sets the tone that it's going for, for sure. However, it wasn't that striking or memorable to me, like I can't think of any tunes as of now. Granted, that's not the only thing video game music is chalked up to do, but it was also pretty homogenous throughout the length and IMO some moments could've been accentuated with even better use of music. Overall, pretty good though. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Interface[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
	[td]The game's not great on a controller. I'd def recommend playing this on mouse, and oddly - on touchscreen? It seems to be made for that, actually. Aside from that, the interface is pretty and def does what it needs to. As I said above though, I kinda wish the whole chapter concept wasn't there.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Pricing & Performance[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
	[td]I'd recommend picking this up on sale. The length might be a problem for some people, but I don't mind a short length. It's not the length itself that I'm referring to here, but how it was used.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Replay Value [/td]
        [td][/td]
	[td]I can see myself pulling out the game or the playthrough video just to show someone the puzzle bit, under certain contexts. Aside from that though, I don't see a reason to go back to the game, and it works as a one-off experience pretty well.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[b]SCORE : 5.6/10[/b]

Falling in love is doomed to parting. Give up love for dreams.The world of adults is boring, and the occasional touch of sweetness is fleeting like a flash in the pan. "Florence" is a beautifully crafted game that tells the story of a young woman's journey of self-discovery and love. The game combines simple gameplay mechanics with stunning visuals and an emotional narrative that pulls the player into the story.

The game's graphics are simple but effective, using bold colors and stylized art to create a charming and whimsical atmosphere. The music is also well-suited to the game's tone, with a soundtrack that complements the visuals and the emotional beats of the story.

The gameplay is straightforward and easy to pick up, with puzzles and challenges that are simple but engaging. The game's mechanics are used to reinforce the themes of the story, such as the way the puzzles become more complex as the protagonist's relationship deepens.

What really sets "Florence" apart, however, is its storytelling. The game's narrative is touching and poignant, exploring themes of love, loss, and personal growth. The story is told through a combination of text, visuals, and gameplay, creating a unique and immersive experience.

Overall, "Florence" is a beautiful and memorable game that tells a heartfelt and resonant story. Its simple gameplay mechanics and stunning visuals serve to enhance its emotional narrative, making it a must-play for anyone looking for a thoughtful and engaging gaming experience.

133541979.review: Florence is a fantastic game that uses visual and auditory storytelling. It has great music, art and a story that made me emotional, though that should be taken with a grain of salt as I'm the type to easily buckle for games like this. It really tugs at your heart as you go alongside Florence, feeling everything she does as she goes through this small snippet of her life. It's a very short game, worth the price I got it for (about $2,) but I easily would've bought it at it's full price. Games that tell a story like these are always some of the best, in my opinion.

133519192.review:
For those who are comfortable with short stories with light gameplay, this is worth a look. I'd say it's one of those cases where it's more about the vibes and the way it's told than the story itself (though I have to give credit that it's nice to see a love story talk about the experience of living together). In other words, the appeal is how mechanics convey story. 
I enjoy seeing how people communicate ideas without words. Of particular note is how Florence conveys the way conversation feels, whether awkward, or sharp and confrontational.
It's a lovely idea what jigsaws can convey with how easily they fit together.

The painting mechanic, which is closely tied to dreams, I find interesting in how it seemingly sets up, pays off, and then is subverted.

It's a nice touch how one of the things you put together early on re-appears a number of times over the game.

Picked up on sale, storytelling with jigsaws has been a nice gentle experience to have at the end of the day.

El OST que maneja esta novela esta a otro nivel, saben perfectamente en que momento cambiar el ambiente, si es de tension, tristeza o felicidad
la paleta de colores y diseño de personajes me parece unica, tiene una paleta de colores atractiva, lo mismo con los personajes
La tematica de la jugabilidad es simple pero significa que sea malo, sino lo contrario, sabe como complementarse con el apartado visual y musical

La aceptacion entre un momento critico en la vida hace pie en florence, me gusto muchisimo la novela y vale la pena darle una oportunidad y comprarla
Aunque no puedo decir lo mismo de su final, la verdad es que lo senti algo apresurado, me hubiese gustado ver como Florence pasaba un estado de negacion a aceptacion, aunque eso se ve en el capitulo "dejalo ir"
Pero me hubiese gustado ver tambien sobre que paso con Krish, ya que a pesar de que Florence sea la protagonista, Krish forma parte de la historia y mas de la mitad de los capitulos esta ahi, aun asi es disfrutable

lo que resalta mas es su banda sonora, me encanto esta novela, la recomiendo completamente!

'The madness known as affirmation, the sickness called belief, the infamy of being happy – all of this reeks of the world, it smacks of this sad thing that’s the earth.

Be indifferent. Love the sunset and the dawn because it does no good, not even for you, to love them. Dress yourself in the gold of the dying afternoon, like a king deposed on a morning of roses in full bloom, with May in the white clouds and the smile of virgins in secluded villas. Let your yearning perish among myrtles, your tedium cease among tamarinds, and may the sound of water accompany all of this as if it were twilight on the banks of a river whose only meaning is to flow – eternal – towards distant seas. The rest is but the life that leaves us, the sparkle in our eyes that fades, the purple robes worn thin even before we don them, the moon that shines down on our exile, the stars that spread their silence over our hour of disillusionment. Assiduous is the sterile and friendly grief that clasps us against its breast with love.'

This is a short slice-of-life VN. It excels in showing us the dev's message, although the emotions portrayed and the message are simple in the first place (in my opinion). It's something I want to point out, not a bad thing really. 

As to the message, if you have lived, you have already seen it. This is more suited for those coming of age.

Others:
- easy achievements. They are non-grindy and you can choose which chapter you want to repeat.
- some minor port issues. Use your keyboard arrow keys if you have to. Other than that, no other bugs. Animation speed is perfect (thankfully, none of those slow walking, slow loading, laggy clicking, slow animation etc).
- the aesthetic (art, colour, music) is quite lovely.

Recommended for teens or young adults.

130365959.review:
[h1]Florence[/h1]
[i]A story about love and life[/i]

[b]Florence[/b] is a short interactive visual style novel about a rudderless young woman in her twenties looking for some sort of meaningful connection in a world that offers very few. [b]Florence[/b] is stuck in an endless routine of the mundane and we understand that she wants to be in love but that the opportunity hasn't presented itself yet.

While out one day, in a meet cute sequence, [b]Florence[/b] meets a busker called Kish who dreams of being an accomplished cello player. At first things seem to come naturally to the two but as the game's vignettes play out we start to see that once the initial courtship is over, [b]Florence[/b] and Kish begin to argue a lot more which leads to the two lovers growing apart.

[b]Florence[/b] is a small slice of life experience that can easily be completed in under 30 min. I can't say I personally felt any emotional connection with the two leads but I can see it resonating with some sectors of the gaming public. It just wasn't personally made for me and that is perfectly fine, not every game is meant to be. 

[h1]One word or phrase to sum up the experience[/h1]
[i]Intimate slice of life story about love, loss and finding yourself.[/i]

[h1]Performance/Bug related incidents[/h1]
[i]Game is designed to run on tablets and phones so no issues with performance. I didn't encounter any issues either[/i]

[h1]Similar to games[/h1]
[i][b]To the Moon[/b], [b]What Remains of Edith Finch[/b], [b]Journey[/b][/i]

[h1]Rating ★★★★★★☆☆☆☆[/h1]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=869454819

130348700.review:
[h1] Very short and cute life story game[/h1]

The game is very short and pretty straight forward. The story itself is nice, nothing groundbreaking but its presentation is actually quite well done.
It's just at the right level where it doesn't get repetitive or too predictable and the art is gorgeous for what it is.
Music is soothing and relaxing. It adapts well to each chapter of our heroine's life.

The way the story is told is the most important part and how it makes you feel like the principal character. There is an illusion of choice which is quite appropriate (because you can't change your life [spoiler]or can you? It's for you to decide once you finish the game[/spoiler]).

I recommend this game to any fans of very short game that can be played in one afternoon/evening (technically even less) and looking for a good story. If you get it on sales, then it's definitely worth it for its very cheap price.

É um jogo curto, com uma historia bem simples. Mas não subestime, eu definitivamente me emocionei e foi definitivamente o momento perfeito pra encontrar esse jogo. É uma historia sobre seguir em frente, sobre encontrar alguém que você ama e que trouxe luz pra sua vida em um momento escuro. Sobre um encontro entre duas pessoas que definitivamente teve seus momentos brilhantes, mas que eventualmente escureceu. E apesar das dores, do sofrimento de deixar algo tão importante pra trás, o mais importante é seguir em frente e entender que tudo foi como deveria ter sido como era pra ser, que doeu, mas que é o momento de deixar o que te segurava pra trás e seguir seus sonhos, seguir sua vida. Como uma artista e por alguém que está tentando ir pra frente depois das recentes turbolescias que minha vida proporcionou, esse jogo é algo que eu precisava.

Algumas coisas não são pra sempre, e ta tudo bem. Pra qualquer pessoa que está lendo e tá passando por isso: vai ficar tudo bem, ok? Vai passar.

Florence is a relaxing game, half an hour long with no words but the idea is made clear.

It's a fairly popular game since it's out but I wasn't interested in seeing the store page. I picked it up during this year's Winter Sale and played on the last day of the year. It tells a simple story between a young couple, how they met, fell in love and[spoiler]let it go. The girl picked up the interest in art only because the boy gifted her the paint, and the boy went to the music academy only because the girl believed he had talent. Sad to see they broke up at the end, however the girl made a successful personal gallery, no info given of the boy but I hope he lives up the dream of performing on a real stage[/spoiler].

This game is more of a visual novel, with simple interactions and mini games. I didn't find it special or touching, but I don't regret my time. Life goes on, sometimes you just let go and live on, time will heal.

Florence

Florence o “Florencia” para los amigos, es un juego que fácilmente puede dividirse en dos grandes partes que se mantienen y se complementan la una a la otra.

El juego.

Florence como juego es un juego difícil de definir… si nunca jugaste un WarioWare para Game Boy Advanced (o DS o Wii o 3DS o Wii U o Switch). Esos juegos eran prácticamente minijuegos en un cartucho. Eso sí, mini juegos divertidos basados en cosas que todos hacemos y podemos identificar rápidamente: lavarte los dientes, hacer cuentas (¡como Donkey Kong Jr. Math!), completar oraciones y limpiar objetos.

Florence, como un buen WarioWare, es corto, muy, muy corto. 48 minutos me fueron más que suficientes para acabarlo. Este tiempo ni siquiera me fue suficiente para obtener mis 3 Steam Cards. 

Eso sí, al acabarlo obtendremos arte conceptual, repertir parted del juego especificas, logros y las Steam Cards aunque no mucho más.

Pero esto no significa que su corta duración sea sinónimo de su calidad, lo cual nos lleva a…

Historia.

Florence, como historia, es un juego que recuerda mucho a Another Lost Phone: Laura´s Story. Si el nombre te suena, es porque también tengo un ensayo sobre él. Al igual que ese juego aquí vemos la historia de una joven mujer llamada “Florence”; vemos su día a día, sus aspiraciones y sus sueños contado a través de minijuegos que también simulan conceptos relacionables. 

A diferencia de Laura´s Story, aquí no hay una relación destructiva de la cual no sabemos si correr, llorar o espantarnos. Aquí solo hay lo que existe en una relación promedio: conocer a alguien, salir con ese alguien y empezar una relación con esa persona. Y al igual que cuando se comienza una relación, aquí van a haber cambios.

¿Qué clase de cambios? Bueno, ese dependerá de cómo lo experimentes tú. 

En términos simples: crecer duele, relacionarse duele y aprender a dejar a ir a las personas también duele. Pero esto no significa que sea algo malo.

Al igual que Florencia, aprender a dejar ir no tiene porque ser malo y algunas veces las relaciones cambian.
No es bueno, ni malo; solo es.

Tu, jugador/a, vas a ver el crecimiento de Florencia. Cómo lo experimentes, dependerá de ti y sólo de ti. 

Para concluir, Florence es un juego diferente a los convencionales juegos “Point & Click”, los desarrolladores claramente tenían una visión acerca de su juego y, en mi opinión, la lograron plasmar de manera fiel a su idea original (la galería de arte nos da una muestra clara de ello). 

Pese a su duración, Florence logra dejar una huella en aquellos que se atrevan a darle una oportunidad.
Daséla.

128271959.review:
This is not a game, this is an almost perfect art work without dialogue! The style of hand-painted art, the music following the ups and downs of the plot, the ingenious interaction of the design, and the hidden small details are all amazing!

Here are some small details worth remembering in the game:

① Three time turntables
My childhood friends and grown up classmates gradually left and went their separate ways. When they were young and ignorant in love, they gradually returned to a lonely life

② Dialogue fragments between male and female leaders
Men and women have different forms of interaction when they meet, know, fall in love, know each other, and even quarrel.
When we meet each other, there are many pieces, small pieces and miscellaneous pieces. We have been busy for a long time, so we can say a word. When we slowly transition to love and familiarity, the pieces of dialogue will be very simple and clear. Finally, when we get together, we need to put together two pieces of pieces at the same time, which also means that love needs to go in both directions. In addition, the game also uses bright red and more sharp and strange dialogue fragments as the dialogue performance when two people quarrel.

③ In the memory, the dream that the male master said freely and the dream that the female master wiped out in the mirror when he was a child may have forgotten.

④ It is gradually pressed under the sundries, and the paint tray is given by the man.

⑤ Let go chapter can choose to stay, but can not save the outcome.

⑥ Open the carton, add the owner's items at home/clean up the traces left by the owner, and close the carton.

⑦ The female owner started again, and once again gathered up the things and closed the cardboard box before the photo with the male owner.

There are a lot of details in the game. The whole process ended in half an hour. The time is a little short. Many fragments have been forgotten when writing the evaluation, but it still left me a lot of deep impression. I think that although this work generally tells a love story, it still shows us more about the life attitude of the female owner. After all, love is not the whole of life.

Perhaps for individuals, family members, lovers, brothers and friends will all become our passers-by. Your family will grow old, and you will form a new family; Lovers and friends will leave, and you can also find another one or a group. Except for ourselves, everyone will only accompany us for a period of time in a certain stage of our life. As time goes by, they will gradually go away for various reasons. Not to mention three lives and three lives, it is a lifetime. Half life and half life may also be an extravagant hope.

Just like the female leader was relieved when she finally saw the photo taken with the male leader, there was a good time in the years of moving forward together, and there was nothing to regret. As for the future, of course, the most important thing is to improve yourself. The more things you will know, the more you will feel resonance. Meeting more people will no longer make them easy passers-by.

Simple and clear hand-painted painting style, non conversational narrative style, accompanied by melodious music, can make me calm down, put aside all trivial matters, and taste this work carefully. Thank you for making me have a good morning!

Ps: When making achievements, I found that there was a scene of quarreling with the male leader, so I could not talk. It's very interesting that whoever quarrels with a lot of words and loud voice will have to coax the other party afterwards. qwq

127913407.review:
OK, this is Edith Finch all over again. What's with Annapurna's love-relationship with social injustice? In Florence, we are basically treated with a story of a young woman's journey to self-love, after a loving relationship that unfortunately "just didn't work". Coupled with amazing visuals and music depicting Singapore, it's not hard for the game to manipulate emotions from us. The game, like in Edith Finch, KNOWS the underlying problems in its story. 

Florence's mom, like so many parents not just in Singapore, disapproves of her interest in painting and Florence ends up with a brain-dead desk job working on spreadsheets. She fell in love with a cellist busker - Florence's life sparked once again. Here's the catch: Florence is Chinese, and the bf, Krish is Indian. The subtle racial divide is forever present, THE GAME DELIBERATELY SHOWS THIS TO YOU: Florence meets and is welcomed by Krish's big Indian family, and his fun friends. However, Krish never had a happy moment with Florence's mom; it is even implied that the mom never knew about Krish at all (in mom's phone call, Florence can still say to mom "not to look for a boyfriend for me"). Still, race is not the issue the caused the love to fall apart - not directly anyway.

The game implies that Florence fell in love with the music more than the musician. This is not the biggest sin in the world, love can grow over time, after all. Krish, through Florence' encouragement, finally enrolled in the prestigious Academy of Music to become the next Yo-Yo Ma. That means full-time study for Krish, and is now dependent on Florence financially. Krish is also supportive of Florence's art - gifting her a watercolour set (!?you give that to a 25-y.o. woman!?) and encourages her to paint. However, the financial strain catches up with the couple; Florence once again has no time for her painting in order to work. She also has no time for Krish, who himself is dedicated full-time in his schooling. Florence is unhappy once again, and they finally broke up. TALE AS OLD AS TIME.

So how will Annapurna end Florence's story? Why, through magical crescendo, of course - which they perfected in Edith Finch. Florence, armed with her watercolour set, discovers that she is a painting prodigy. Chinese mom finally came to her senses and is now supportive of her, now that her talents can be made into a business. Familial love triumphs all, Florence is happy and her watercolour paintings are being exhibited with obviously rich patrons. So how about the Indian guy who presumably is still toiling at the Academy? Nope, no mention of him again, now that Florence essentially won the Race Lottery. 

So what does Annapurna teach us, kids? Race, gender, abuse, they do not matter once you become a Venture Capitalist in Silicon Valley.

127465912.review:
----- EVERYTHING BELOW IS SPOILER FREE -----

Florence is beautiful. Its a shows the search for happiness and how bumpy life can be sometimes.

Graphics: The artwork of this game is simplistic. It allows you to absorb the story being told and really engage with whats being shown to you. It allows you to suck up every last detail and spares you time to just soak it in when you need it.

Gameplay: Much like the artwork of this game, the gameplay stays simplistic. There is absolutely nothing to subtract from the experience. You control the speed that the story play out and please take it as chilled out as you want. Want to go fast? feel free but it'll only detract from your experience. Want to just sit back and let the music take you away? yes... yes you do!

Audio: The music that plays throughout the game will be music i listen to for some time to come. Its simply beautiful. Every single moment. Please just play it even if you only do it for the calming songs that get sprinkled throughout. The game lets the music set the tone and lets the players mind do the rest of the work to make you just... feel something. I believe everyone's life experiences and feelings that come from the songs will drastically change your emotions that occur during the story and effect the time you have during its short run.

Audience: The type of person that would want to play this is someone who wants to just grab a cup of coffee, sit back, and just... let go.

PC Requirements: You can play on a potato if you want but bring some damn headphones with you cause it'll only make the experience better for you.

Difficulty: Only difficulty i see is from this is the difficulty of recovering after such a wonderful experience.

Grind: If you find a grind in-game let me know cause i didn't find any but i have had to start grinding therapy sessions after finishing it and realising i wont be able to play it again for the first time.

Story: The story is a short and sweet section of girls life who goes by the name Florence Yeoh. You will be introduced to Krish and the way you will feel begins from that. Enjoy.

Game Time: I finished in roughly 45 minutes but play time will vary because i did sit at multiple sections to listen to the music, just for a second. I didn't sit for very long at these sections as i have the sound track that i'm gonna jam out to later but if you don't you'll have the same feeling of wanting to sit and listen, i'm sure :)

Price: The price of this game is worth it if you've got money to spend. I got it at £1.58 on sale but after playing it i would say the full £4.79 is worth it if you like these kinds of games.

Bugs: I didn't experience any. I wish i did cause it might've got me stuck listening to these bangers for longer :p
