126431192.review:
Florence is simple, relatable, and fun to play. It's not in my top ten list but has still managed to leave an impression. 

Pros: Lovely soundtrack, an ending I didn't expect but was certainly pleased with, and I really appreciated how the way you're prompted to engage with the gameplay adds emphasis to how the lead characters are feeling, particularly when they're in conversation with each other. 

Cons: The gameplay itself. It feels like a walking simulator without being one. What I mean by that is that you're prompted to do certain repetitive tasks such as tapping buttons or moving the mouse so Florence brushes her teeth in order to go with what's happening on screen with little to no meaningful choice. While some aspects of this can be engaging, such as how they approach dialogue interactivity, other aspects are not and feel like more of a hindrance than not. That being said, you could argue that's part of the point if you don't mind it because it's meant to represent the repetativeness of her daily life. It just wasn't my favorite part of the game.

124995668.review:
Hoy he terminado Florence. 
A ver que puedo contaros sobre este juego

Arte 
Florence utiliza un estilo de dibujo hecho a mano que va muy bien con las escenas emotivas que nos va mostrando, haciéndolas incluso más grandes (que ya de por sí lo son)

Banda sonora
La banda sonora es simple pero efectiva, aunque algunas veces se hace un poco repetitiva. Eso sí, va haciendo pausas para darle más hincapié a las escenas más importantes.

Historia
Una historia bastante típica pero es contada desde un punto de vista en el que casi seguro que todos nos hemos visto reflejados en algún momento de nuestras vidas. Pero lo muestra con un formato de videojuegos que no podemos dejar de parar e interactuar con cada escena que nos va mostrando.

Gameplay
Como ya he dicho el estilo de juego es una sucesión de capítulos hechos con minijuegos que nos harán ir interactuando con la historia para hacernos partícipes de cada acción que realicemos.

Valor 
Es un juego rápido de pasar, pero está bien cuidado con muchos detalles tan bien pensados que no te lo esperas. Si acaso esperaría a que haya una pequeña oferta pero ni siquiera el precio normal actual (5 €) es caro.

Como siempre Annapurna nos deja un buen sabor de boca como hace con todos sus juegos. Si os gustan las experiencias emocionales bien hechas. Ponerlo en la lista de deseados y en el peor de los casos de que no lo pilleis puede que alguien os lo regale con cariño.

124391225.review: Lovely game. Very human & compassionate. I enjoyed this. Doesn't expect much out of you except to presently experience and move the story along using some very cool, smooth, and novel mechanical elements (a little more than point and click, it's fun). It's really cute, and creatively designed. It reads like an interactive, animated graphic novel. Beyond that, the other reason I like this game is because it was easy to imagine actually being in the protagonist's shoes..  Experiencing the story intimately with the characters and being absorbed by playing out the narrative. "Florence" is unique and worth checking out. Well done! Also, you can go back to earlier chapters whilst playing, if you wanted to change a previous action or have to go back for an achievement.

124381820.review:
Let me tell you about the gameplay and my afterthoughts, separately. First the technical aspects:
The machanics of the game and very innovative, and while simple, handled very cleverly by the makers. Props to that! I was having a good time playing all the different puzzles. They were pretty cool. For that alone, I'll give it a positive note.

Now spoilers regarding the story:

I was looking forward to experiencing the story of a hopeful, dreamy-eyed girl, possibly witnessing a cute romance. What it has left me with was a feeling of crushing failure and sadness. Poor girl, grasping at the need to fulfill her life with something meaningful. Something that could be called occupational therapy - making art. 
A girl focuses her time on something bringing her serenity and even money and recognition. While standing alone in her room, smiling to the memory of a nice man who brought her inspiration, yet is no longer in her life. What a bitter, sad story about realising your faults and healing some bonds (with mom), while losing - perhaps forever - others (I can't imagine the family of her boyfriend would still be in touch with her).
Despite all the bright colors and pleasant music, I can't bring myself to play again. It's not a sweet story with a happy ending. The sweetness all the love and compationship the two people had makes it that more tearful, when it's cut short. Perhaps it will speak to some younger people with a full life ahead of them... For me personally it lacks the positivity I was looking for. 
Maybe make a sequel, where these two mature and make up? Realise they indeed can bring out the best in one another?

Florence is a beautiful experience that isn’t afraid to tell an ordinary story. You act out the simple life of Florence Yeoh, who feels like her life is an endless routine of work, sleep, trying to keep your parents of her back and spending too much time on social media. Eventually romance finds it's way into the mix, but relationships aren't always forever.

In Florence, you break the ordinary cycle of her life, you find love, but eventually move on and in the end find new inspirations for her life and life goes on. 

It's a simple game, with not much gameplay elements, some small point and click aspects, but otherwise it's mostly just watching the story unfold. It's a very short game, took me an hour to 100% with some downtime in between chapters. It's a very impactful story nonetheless and it's quite intimate and raw with it's emotions. Definitely a small little game worth playing, even at full price.

121902883.review:
I bought this game really liking the music, art style and concept. I played, I cried, I shared it with my boyfriend because I knew he'd love the way the game was executed. He played and was also really touched by it, and I can even see it right now that he had marked this game on his wish list. The game stuck with me after playing for quite a long time, because certain parts felt familiar...in a bad way. But I refused to recognise that maybe my relationship wasn't going anywhere. Fast forward a bit, found out my boyfriend of 5 years whom I shared the game with was being unfaithful to me, with my best friend of 13 years. The painful ordeal of breaking up dragged on for a month and I had to witness a lot of ugliness. Then a ton of shitty things happened afterwards. Recently opening up my Steam after almost a year of not daring to touch it brought back a lot of emotions. I saw this game, listened to the familiar music and kind of just broke down and cried. It brought back memories of me playing it the very first time, of me sharing it with my ex-boyfriend, and of the past in general. It's still an amazing game, I want to replay it again once everything hurts a bit less, hopefully to remind myself that things will be better for me too in due time, just like in the game. It's a very beautiful and well made game, give it a try, it's worth your time. (Set. 7th 2022)
UPDATE: It's almost a year since I posted the original review, and a bit more than 1.5  years since my breakup. I has sunken into severe depression after what happened, details aren't necessary but I was deeply let down by my significant other, my best friend, and my family. The blow was devastating, I didn't think I could ever pick up the pieces of myself and recover to a state that I could continue to live with. Life felt pointless. Somehow I still struggled on, even though days blurred together, even though I had nothing to look forward to tomorrow, I still waited for the next day. I'm happy to say that it was worth it. Recently, after 1.5 years I'm finally starting to feel better. I'm finally able to accept what took place and the way it's changed my life. I still struggle with a lot of stuff but I'm laughing again, I'm listening to music again, things bring me joy again, and however trivial the reason may be, there is a point to life again. I remembered this game and I came back and played it again today. I once again struggled a lot with the chapter about moving on, just like in real life. And I felt uneasy during the honeymoon stages of the game, since I already knew how it would end. Interestingly enough, this is why I've not dated, made friends or had much social interaction since. My faith in relationships and friendships did not recover, and a part of me don't think it ever will, but I look forward to the day where life proves me wrong. Just like in the game my relationship with my mother improved, a happy coincidence! I've picked back up cooking once again, and it's brought me a lot of joy. Although unlike Michelle, I have no plans of turning my hobby into a job! xD I'm in a much better place right now, and I look forward to replaying the game in a few years to see how it makes me feel then. It's still an excellent game that I recommend anyone and everyone to play. (Aug. 6th 2023)

Florence is a game about a young girl who wishes she had done more with her life until she meets someone who shows her she still can. The game starts off with blacks, grays and whites to show how monotony her life is. Color shows up later to show that her life has meaning and is bright. Using color in this way shows more about the attitude of her life than others might think. On top of all that, I think Florence is a gal we all young adults can relate to. A feeling of having to be the responsible adult vs. going out and doing what we actually want to do.

120942537.review:
Florence is an artsy experience that ends very quickly. It's barely a game and more of an interactive short story.

The gameplay is button presses and swipes to advance the scenes. Like a visual novel if you please. Mostly. You do some different things but nothing with depth or skill level. It fits though, and everything you do make sense with what is happening in the scenes.

The art, music and overall feeling is where the meat is, and it's done wonderfully. It looks great and has a lot of style. The story is quite predictable but told nicely and with a lot of love. The visual style and effects make the fact that you do very little still feel good and complements the story. Like the puzzle pieces when structuring dialogues which reflects the mood of the conversations. Soft and round when happy and sharper and pointy when angry. Small details like that are abundant and impressed me quite a few times.

All in all, it's very short and semi-self-playing but told well enough. Give it a shot if these kinds of artsy indie short stories interests you. I'm not sure I feel 5 bucks to be worth it, unless you really want to support the devs, but in a sale; absolutely. It took me less than an hour to 100%. I bought it for a buck or so and got my money's worth.

120591645.review:
[h1][url=store.steampowered.com/app/1102130/Florence/]Florence[/url] invites the player to never stop chasing their dreams and reminds them of the importance of brushing their teeth regularly.[/h1]

Play through assorted life snapshots of a young Chinese-Australian woman and relive a few of her childhood memories. Each animated vignette presents lovely visuals with vibrant colors and a preeminent soundtrack that strongly enlivens these mini chapters.

Scenes typically move forward like a storybook by scrolling down. Sometimes up. Some side-swiping mouse interactions felt less responsive, a reminder that this title was initially designed with a touch interface in mind.

Otherwise, the player must sort through uncommonly simple mini games that present an interesting collection of ideas but rarely evolve into significant interactions. Most of them represent everyday moments, while some shape more meaningful branching points in Florence's life that ultimately reveal her true self.

Simulate conversations without words using reconstructed speech bubbles. Shake life into Polaroids. Solve elementary math equations. Float up to catch musical notes. Bring images into focus after a blur. There many more such segments that last a few seconds each. All interactions appear designed for young children in their ultra-simplicity.

Florence does not eat the crusts of her toast or pizza. She tags social media likes on her work commute. She savors sushi while watching TV. She works spreadsheets but, ultimately, she desires to earn a living selling kaleidoscopic pastel paintings instead. She could be anyone.

This is a story about ordinary life, sadly accurate and probably relatable to most average people on different levels, without a Hollywood happy ending or any profound impact. Sympathetic, honest, common. It stands out compared to the average landscape of video game history but still has no replay value outside of achievements.

Inconsequential phone conversations with Florence's mother where choices don't matter make her relationship with mum feel utterly pointless. Same with how you choose items to keep or put in a box when moving together with Krish, or any of the linear actions presented, really.

I expected more feels given the significant amount of praise received by this title on multiple platforms. Sort of bittersweet with a somewhat positive message to keep chasing your dreams but it's all a bit too ordinary. There were some good moments, like the unmatched and drifting puzzle pieces as a metaphor for difficult conversations, where no one wins the argument.

Extremely short, completed under 1hr (I played it twice several months apart only to see if it would resonate more). I love concise experiences, but this is excessively condensed, as you fast forward through Florence's life with barely enough time to get emotionally invested in anything or anyone.

Like the game itself, this is a bittersweet recommendation that barely passes the mark.

[h1]Positive[/h1]
[list]
[*] Lovely visuals with vibrant colors
[*] Preeminent soundtrack strongly enlivens animated vignettes
[*] Bittersweet but positive message
[*] Several relatable everyday scenes
[*] Sympathetic and honest
[*] Includes early concept art gallery
[/list]

[h1]Negative[/h1]
[list]
[*] Ultra simple mini games fall flat
[*] Every single activity is inconsequential
[*] Florence's life relationships feel pointless
[*] Low effort to convert touch-controls for mouse interactions
[*] Extremely short
[/list]

120398638.review:
Florence

Story📖 9/10
Florence tells the story of the titular young woman falling in and out of love for the first time with a young man named Krish. In terms of its storytelling, much of the game’s narrative will feel relatable, particularly to young women who remember restricting parts of themselves to make a partner more comfortable, or who reminisce on ignored early warning signs with partners long gone.

While the story is short, and not necessarily breaking new ground for romance narratives, what makes Florence special is the intuitive, accessible, and beautifully conceptualized ways that gameplay is used to replicate the feel of many moments in Florence’s relationship journey. The plot itself may be simple, but the ways you interact with story beats really help to emotionally draw the player into feeling the emotions on display without requiring characters to outright say how they feel.

A wonderful example of this is the way conversations in the game are often represented by touch screen puzzle speech bubbles, where the player has to take their time slowly putting together the next sentence to be said, awkwardly struggling to make the conversation flow. As the couple gets more comfortable with each other, the puzzles are made of fewer and fewer pieces, flowing more quickly and requiring less thought and care. Arguments are far too easy, with insults thrown out without any assembly required, and apologies are perhaps some of the most difficult to piece together.

Florence is a short and simple game, but one full to the brim with heart and charm. It’s only a couple of dollars, but it’s well worth taking half an hour to stick on some headphones, find a quiet space alone, and sitting to play through it in a single sitting

Game Play🎮 8/10
Graphic 👀     8/10
Music🎼         10/10

https://www.syfy.com/

120274382.review:
Slice of life as a genre is the most common choice for everyone of us. It doesn't matter if we talk about literature and simultaneously about movies or games. Many of us are curious about certain challenges, feelings, situations, which is why probably there is never ending wave of stories created for viewers, readers and every gamer. 

Also, for self-care, comforting and balancing, we seek among fictional stories for something that can resemble our experiences, and through seeing the fictional resemblance of them, it might help us in cooping with those. In case of "Florence" all of us might admit, that this game has sort of therapeutic character and show us shine and darkness behind life experiences. 

As we follow the story of a protagonist-girl exposed to dreams, goals, while also looses and heartbreaking moments, we might find in each part of it something very likely as our own experiences. Simple puzzle elements of the game, scrolling, painting, uncovering the pictures or little bit of self-choice thing - are very well cooping with each chapter and overall design. 

"Florence" does not force on you being fast; this is that sort of a game, which perfectly suits a players for which peaceful moment and casual games are what they are seeking for. Between doing some online training and courses, I had been playing in this game on my breaks. It took me in total about 1 hour to finish the whole story, re-do about 3 chapters and gain all possible achievements. Which is absolutely - not bad.


This position, might be also an inspirational thing, or something bringing healthy culmination for all of those gamer and people, who are indecisive or struggle with "letting go". 


Yes. Releasing things from abandoning toxicity through discovering a potential, might be the shortest summarise for the morals presented in that game. Yet, please let yourself exploring it on your own, and by your individual perspective reach to the most adequate for you conclusions. 

If that descriptions convinced you, then give it a try. This is a simple game, quite cheap (even during promotions) so very finest for low budget players, people enjoying real-life stories and those of you who enjoy visual minimalism. Just saying'.

120110494.review:
[i]Florence[/i] is the result of developers disregarding the first rule of the ye olde game-making testament - [b][i]Time : content ratio[/i][/b]. Instead, they decided to tell a story via [i]Florence[/i], length be damned. So you lot who measure the game's worth by that, in my opinion, absurd criteria, please move along. [i]Florence[/i] is not for you.

[i]Florence[/i] is for those more interested in the journey and the memories it begets. So accompany Florence in this short, slice-of-life game about taking chances, happiness, monotony, moving on, and all that fun life jazz, as you witness all her ups and downs as she attempts to adult. And I'll leave the story synopsis at that, as experiencing it firsthand is the core of this adventure, and it wouldn't be right of me to rob you of it.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2829241828

But I will talk a bit about the visuals, which serve as the narrator in this mute game. I love the minimalistic, stark, cartoonish look. Depending on the scene, the backgrounds go from brimming with detail to completely absent. In some cases, they are nought but a single solid colour. However, I understand why this was done. As it is situational, it occurs only in instances where the background could potentially deter from the individual. Thus, the developers managed to further highlight certain bits on your screen with this trick. So no foul here.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2827391375

Visual cues are also a big part of certain puzzles, especially the grocery store dialogue jigsaw puzzle. That was just amazing. And it's a damn shame there weren't more puzzles that "[i]evolve[/i]" during gameplay. Still, they managed to make puzzles feel connected to the story by having them also convey Florence's emotions. [b][i]They aren't just some pointless puzzles, detached from what's happening on your screen[/i][/b], serving only one purpose - accommodating some form of interaction between the game and the player. No. They also partake in telling this story of Florence and her attempt at adulting. And best of all, these puzzles are simple, swift, with no-fail conditions, and above all else, just fun to do. There were some repeats, mainly the dialogue jigsaw puzzles, but they also have [i]visible[/i] differences I rather not spoil, which made them [i]fresh[/i]. And this goes for the rest of the catalogue - [b][i]even if there are occasional puzzle repeats, the game's puzzle catalogue has enough variation that I didn't mind the occasional misstep.[/i][/b]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2845011379

So there you have it, [i]Florence[/i]. Finishing the game will probably take you the same amount of time it took you to read this review ([i]probably a bit more, but humour me[/i]), but is that so bad? [b]I say ney![/b] The most important thing be if some piece of the game sticks with you long after the credits roll. And [i]Florence[/i] manages that by dealing with the ups and downs of [b]adulting[/b], something many of us are all too familiar with.

[quote]If you enjoy this review, come and read more wisdom from the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/40407656-Gospel-of-Sv.-Prolivije/]Gospel of Sv. Prolivije[/url].

118758410.review: I first came across Florence on the App Store when it was first released but thought it wasn’t worth the price at the time. After seeing it on Steam at a lower price a few years later, I was excited to give it a go. However, I was very disappointed to realize that the tasks (or puzzles if you can call them that) in this interactive storybook become very repetitive and boring (such as the constant need to complete speech bubbles using the same mechanics). Also, there was obvious evidence of pretty lazy game design as I had to like the same pictures when the character was on social media on two different occasions in the story. But my absolute biggest issue and frustration with Florence was not being able to see the cursor when playing on my Mac! Whether full-screen or not I had to guess where the cursor was almost all the time which was super annoying. This was most certainly a bug as I was able to see a hand instead of my cursor on the screen a few times but it only lasted for a few seconds before then disappearing. This game was clearly designed for devices with touchscreens and not laptops and the developers had not bothered with converting it to a stable laptop experience. This is also obvious when looking at the settings menu where you can turn "vibrations" on or off?! This was basically not at all what I was expecting, especially with the positive reviews that I had seen. It did have a relatively relatable storyline that may speak to many but the monotony and over-simplicity of the player's interactivity with the story along with the very irritating bug definitely ruined it for me.

118502713.review:
Story is basic, but the methods of storytelling are incredibly cool. 

Florence is not like most other games: There is no win or lose, nor any way to change or affect how the story plays out. It's best described as an "interactive story": You go from story beat to story beat, each one having some element to interact with.

What's fascinating is how much the interactive elements tell the story. I've never seen a game before demonstrate how game mechanics can not just [i]assist[/i] in telling the story but [i]be[/i] the thing telling the story. You can't do these things in other forms of media. 

Unfortunately, the game is very short and the story is extremely basic (although, to its credit Florence not trying to be a more-than-basic story so this aspect is not a sign of failure on the devs, but it still makes the story slightly underwhelming).

But still, the visuals are gorgeous, the music is great, and the experience offered is very special.

I finished the game in less than an hour. The story is very simple, short, and generic. However, the presentation is excellent. This is something Annapurna Interactive is always great at. The game is able to convey a lot of inner thoughts of the characters without any word or explicit visual or audio cues. They do it simply by interaction design as if intuition is a sense of its own. Most players will be able to understand and appreciate what and why the game is made the way it is. Everything is implicitly presented, but easy for the player to understand.

I always feel that the games from Annapurna should be treated as textbook materials for game design courses. They are very unique and experimental, yet effective. About price, it's worth it if it's on discount, but it's too short if you are paying full price.

Ok to be fair, I don't dislike this game, and the art is beautiful. Too bad steam won't allow neutral reviews

That being said, however, I can't help but feel completely indifferent throughout the game. I just can't relate. Why is it that the only way a 25 year-old woman can find something different in her life is through meeting a guy? Why is it that she can only find her purpose after breaking up with a guy? Also, is Krish even attractive? no offense but I can't see what makes him attractive. Krish is a (presumably) 25 year-old who is, at best, a street artist, or as we all know, just some random dude busking on the street. He's got a room as messy as a trash can, got nothing to do in his mid 20s, and he needs his girlfriend to encourage him to even apply to music school. Just what do you see in him, Florence?

Was this game worth the price? Yeah, because I got it at $1.99. Was it worth my time? Probably not. Maybe I just went in with too much expectations.

116379314.review:
[h1] 𝔽𝕝𝕠𝕣𝕖𝕟𝕔𝕖 𝕣𝕖𝕔𝕠𝕦𝕟𝕥𝕤 𝕤𝕠𝕞𝕖𝕥𝕙𝕚𝕟𝕘 𝕒𝕝𝕝 𝕡𝕖𝕠𝕡𝕝𝕖 𝕙𝕒𝕧𝕖 𝕤𝕦𝕗𝕗𝕖𝕣𝕖𝕕 𝕥𝕙𝕣𝕠𝕦𝕘𝕙 𝕠𝕟𝕖 𝕨𝕒𝕪 𝕠𝕣 𝕒𝕟𝕠𝕥𝕙𝕖𝕣 𝕚𝕟 𝕒 𝕧𝕖𝕣𝕪 "𝕣𝕖𝕒𝕝" 𝕨𝕒𝕪! [/h1]

This short, almost an hour long game is a trip down memory lane for most of us. It's a point-and-click adventure that's very linear and to the point and that will probably have the most sensitive bunch in tears halfway through.

Florence uses an amazing hand-drawn artstyle to tell the story of bored, working half-a-day shifts, accountant Florence Yeoh. Instead of following through with her passion, she chose the easier path that most of us find ourselves in; needless to say, that same path has led her to be an accountant, which is a job she dreads. 

Florence keeps going through her mundane, routine activities, bored, unambitious and in disbelief as her life is wasted before her eyes... until she meets Krish! Krish also suffers from this horrible routine, so he and Florence found common ground and fell in love. However, as you might have already experienced, love is usually one-sided and as Florence pushes Krish to pursue his passion for music, she keeps her love for painting all in as she goes through her mundane activities. She keeps thinking that he's worth everything, that he's the very first person to ever love her, so she keeps thinking that her passion is less worthy than his... Krish moves in, and Florence is happy... but Krish hates routine, the same routine Florence has been accustumed to for very long... Krish craves change, he loves to travel, to meet new people while Florence is more of a "settling" type. Years pass, and as the tension rises between Florence and Krish, she will experience one of her worst losses yet.

Florence is an amazing game that I recommend to everyone; even if they hate point-and-click games. It is just "real", out of real life, that deals with an issue that most of us have dealt with before or will inevitabely have to deal with later in our lives. My only complaint is that it was quite short, but for what it's trying to convey, the short length of the game actually adds to the charm. [b]8/10[/b] story that asks nothing of you but to interpret what the characters are actually saying.

116255954.review:
[h1]Florence.[/h1]
[i][url= https://youtu.be/JR85nKaO--4]”I’m always gonna love you.”[/url][/i]

First and foremost, I'd like to share my own impressions of this game. I can't say that the game drastically changed me on the inside, though now that I've replayed it 4 years after my first playthrough, I feel and understand that this short smartphone gaming session that I had back in 2018 left a small, but tangible mark in my soul. Which is probably also true for many other people. This overview is my token of appreciation for Annapurna Interactive and Mountains for all the emotions I've experienced by diving into this minute, yet dazzling creation.

Factually, the game is a visual novel with a set of mini games, accompanied by peaceful, inspiring, tense and simply sad, yet always very beautiful music, which changes depending on what's going on in the main character's life. The mechanics used for interacting with the player wonderfully portray our current everyday lives, which we thankfully or unfortunately still have to live. I won't give any spoilers away, though it doesn't even make sense to attempt to describe anything, because even though the game is very short, it's an emotional, and even intimate journey at times, which is best experienced on your own for the first time, without knowing any details. And that's because every single mini-game or mechanic will be perceived differently by every individual player, since they are related to the things everyone faces in their real lives one way or another. So your perception of all these things and the reactions evoked in response to them are exactly the experience and feelings which will be unique for everyone, even though, in my opinion, the developers' intended answer was rather simplistic and straight-forward at the end of the game.

116251544.review:
Some people are too critical in their reviews saying it was unoriginal or it had a shallow storyline and such.  (yes I'm calling you out Razz and oxy) This "game" is a simple story/visual novel. It doesn't have extravagant graphics or compelling mechanics that make you wanna play over and over again or anything. The reason why this game is so special is because the exact reason its not, Florence and Krish are not famous, they aren't special, they aren't people that any of us would have ever known unless we lived near them or stumbled upon them at the local grocery store. These are average people with hopes and dreams and you delve into a quick blip of Florence's life. The reason why its so special is because there are THOUSANDS of these stories happening everyday. It tells a story of the beautiful happenings of life and relationships, its beautiful because of its sadness and happiness, its beautiful because its real. I can't tell you its a good game but I can tell you its a good story and for those who think that it is an unoriginal story, take a look at your lives. We are all writing the same story for ourselves, we all have written a review for this game which means our very lives are unoriginal and boring. People do the same things all day every day 7 days a week and yet some people can still find the beauty of living and writing reviews on video games 

TLDR: Just because its not new or original doesn't mean it can't be beautiful :)

116227797.review:
Florence is a game with beautiful art and a wonderful soundtrack, and that's about it. It's only 40 minutes long and could barely hold my attention for its entire runtime. The story is just so unoriginal and ordinary that I'm confused why they wasted so much talent to tell it.

Nonetheless, I like this coloring book story format and clearly the team behind this game is ultra capable. Some of the minigames were creative ideas, and I swear if they just had an actual writer on staff this would be an absolute banger. I mean, that soundtrack is out of this world good. 116151024.review:
Since I had just finished Hitman 3 the day prior, I thought why not boot up a 45-minute long Annapurna game before my birthday to ease things down.

Visually, it isn't as unique as Gorogoa or Journey as it sticks to a simple [i]'color-wash over rough sketch'[/i] look but that was fine for the simple young-adult romance story of 2 Asians living in a western country genre that it was going for, and actually worked well as a [b]deceiving medium.[/b] The art style may remind you of wholesome webcomics, but they were really able to get you in the feels with the melancholic shift by the end.

[spoiler]I liked the part where the speech bubble puzzle required lesser and lesser pieces as they talked more. a cool metaphor for starting to understand each other more, hence requiring lesser words for conversation. In the groceries chapter, we see Krish's bubbles being available to be placed by us as well as he was now part of us, and the speedy dialogues do represent the way we hastily argue at an irritating point of a relationship.

We see no closure as to what happened with Krish... that aspect hurt a bit as it's too real for me. Block and forget is the way things go I guess... [/spoiler]

Overall, the interactivity is minimal as there is no puzzle solving, but the sort-of minigames exist just to convey a meaning like the ones I've mentioned above. The soundtrack is a Piano and violin medley, like every Annapurna game, but it isn't too subdued or ambient so it's fun enough to listen to without the game.

115188931.review:
[h1]Beautiful art, Puddle-deep story[/h1]
To be concise, the art is very pretty, there's a significant amount of care in every scene, and the music is fantastic. All of this is, sadly, in service of telling a non-story. This is a narrative-centric game, so the fact that all it has to show for a narrative is [spoiler]girl meets boy, they begin a relationship, they break up, they get over it[/spoiler] is honestly embarrassing. 
And I actually happen to like these kind of soft indie art games, but jesus is this story tired. It's not just the fact that it's the exact same story that is the go-to for these games when they don't want to hire an actual writer, it's also that it has nothing new to say about any part of it. Adding insult to injury, the entire thing seems to be entirely made up of tired clichés. [spoiler]Girl crushes on a street musician? ✓ check. They have their meetcute when she clumsily falls in front of him? ✓ check. He buys her a little box of watercolors to encourage her to go back to doing art? ✓ check, check, check.[/spoiler] 

[b]Conclusion[/b]
If you enjoy the art in the screenshots and the music in the trailer, and expect nothing more, it's [i]fine[/i]. It's not even very long, and going by the other reviews some people seem to have gotten a lot more than I did out of the story so hey YMMV. For me it's just not enough to overlook the fact that (allegedly) the founder of the studio made the other developer's lives a living hell while making it.

Florence looks so cool that for several years I looked at it, greedily clutching 2 bucks in my hand, which I could've spent on it on fairly frequent discounts. And I finally did it. And regretted it.

It's not really a game, it's an interactive PowerPoint presentation that often interrupts the flow with trivial and tedious tasks, among which there are: put two numbers together 10 times, put together a puzzle of 3 pieces 10 times, brush your teeth by moving the mouse a couple of times, and so on. Puzzles are story connected, but this does not help, since they are connected only slightly.

The whole paragraph above would not be so bad if the story pulled everything on it's back, but it is not capable of that. The theme of the game can be reduced to "even from bad relationships/situations in life, you need to/can take something positive." Good theme, but it has been explored without any nuance, and therefore I can't call this story even a little interesting. Also, game's "beautiful music" guided me to the kingdom of Morpheus.

An hour spent in Florence felt longer than 4 hours spent in TOEM. I could spend this hour on half of La La Land, for example, the story of it strongly resembles the story of Florence, only everything is more interesting and nuanced. Refund.

I seem to be a big fan of emotional AnnaPurna games about relationships and processing grief because I've found myself playing and enjoying yet another one! 

This game is quite short (it took me about 50 minutes to complete the story the first time, then about 15 minutes more to go through selected chapters to 100% the achievements), but very poignant and beautiful, so for me, it was worth it. It's like an interactive short story and I love those. Some lovely creative visual storytelling, even with no dialogue it conveys its story and emotion perfectly. 113530912.review:
Are you sick of your ordinary life, with your daily routine being like: sleep, wake up, going to a boring job, having almost no social life and being single?
Welcome to "Florence"!
Florence, a 25y.o. girl, works as an accountant (a job that she doesn't really like), probably because it gives her a financial stability. Her dream is to become an artist,but haven't really tried to chase it so far. One day , she meets Krish, a young man with a dream of becoming a musician.They fall in love, creating beautiful memories, moving together etc.Most importantly, they help each other grow, pursuing their dreams in life. After a while, as it is common, people grow apart, fighting all the time and feeling constantly sad, incomplete/empty, anxious and decide its best for both of them to break up. 
And exactly at this point, is where the magic begins ( at least for me )!
Florence, after accepting their break up, begins to draw again, spending most of her time - if not all of it - practicing day and night and finally her dream comes true! She succeeds on becoming what she really wanted to be! 
She is HAPPY, ALL BY HERSELF!

So, at this point I just want to say, it's never too late to do what you love. Most of the times it's YOU and ONLY YOU against the world. Even the people you trust or you expect some kind of support won't be by your side. It's okay, you can do it without them. Stand on your feet, face the challenge and say "I CAN do it. I WILL SUCCEED".
Congratulations, you 're one step closer to your goal. I'm proud of you!

113504098.review:
Basically, it's a short comic book told through a minigame format. The minigames aren't anything to write home about, and there...isn't a lot of story here. Basically it's every Hallmark movie ever - Florence is the straight-laced overachieving business type character who has a job but nothing else in her life and is miserable, and Krish is the manic-pixie dream boy with a rebellious and creative streak who shows up and teaches her about stopping to smell the roses and that there's more to life or whatever.

So at least props for swapping the normal genders I guess! 

I also respect the very grounded take on adult life, despite the Hallmark plot, you have probably lived Florence's life before. Very real. 

It also doesn't last very long, you'll finish it pretty quick. The picture roll at the top of the steam page is actually a pretty big chunk of the game...

That said, it's still unique and pretty good. A little light for a steam game but exactly the right size for a bite-sized mobile game, which is what it is. As a game in the minigame bundle genre like Warioware or Rhythm Heaven, it doesn't stand up. As a comic strip, it also doesn't stand up. But as a crossing of both those things? It's pretty cool, I've never seen anything like it before. I'm reminded of the scene from Ratatouille, where Remi eats the apple and it makes a sound, and then the cheese and it makes a sound - but then both *together* and the screen blows up pink with fireworks and the music swells? Yeah it's like that, more than the sum of it's parts.

Florence is a cool as a comic book that is also a game, their use of interactive elements through minigames as symbolism to explain what's going on in the story and make you participate is a unique format and it's neat for that alone. If you're expecting to have your mind blown by a deep and groundbreaking story, you're going to be disappointed. If you're expecting to have crazy fun with tight controls and engaging gameplay, you'll also be disappointed. But if you're expecting to be wowed by the clever use of gameplay mechanics as storytelling and admire the artistry of the interactive medium... this is the right place.

Good but probably overhyped, temper your expectations and you'll be happy.

A solid "Huh. Neat" out of 10, worth the $2

113195879.review:
Ultimately, the game was short, but the time spent playing was worthwhile due to it's message and how the MC's story was presented.  The art and music present the creator's style in a simple, yet poignant way.  Each feeling in the moment you're playing the game translates through to the vibrancy or lack of color in the art style.  The music is so emotionally charged that it negates the need for subtitles and voice-overs, and connects you to the character's thoughts and feelings seamlessly. 

The story is immersive and rich enough that it completely takes you on a roller coaster of emotions, much like the MC Florence Yeoh experiences as you're playing the game.  I love how it captures the essence of a realistic love story without the fluff and unrealistic elements most visual novels have, while representing the struggles of a child trapped between discovering themselves and being dutiful to their parent and their expectations.  Florence is an indie game I'd recommend to those who can appreciate the thoughtfulness that went into this rich story, and overlook the fact it's a short compilation of mini-games.

I really liked Florence, but there are a few things that I think that buyers should beware of.

1. Florence is NOT a long game. It could be finished in less than two hours.
2. It is NOT a game that has different endings to explore, and it is not something I would consider re-playable for the average gamer.

That being said, Florence is a work of art. Its hand drawn visuals are charming and its obvious that a lot of love went into writing and making this game. It's a thoughtful, story-based point and click game where the player joins Florence as she discovers what she is passionate about. The story is relatable and wholesome. 

I bought Florence on sale for half price, and i feel that the amount of time i spent with it was worth the money. I would not purchase this game at full price if you are looking for something that you can sink a lot of time into. But if you are someone who enjoys art, music, and the point and click style, give Florence a try.

111959078.review:
This game hit a lot differently than I had expected the game to.  I had thought this would be a romance story (perhaps a with a more hopeful and ideal outcome) where Florence would find romance, find her dream, and live happily ever after.  In comparison, what I got was a lot more realistic, and more raw with emotion than I had thought.

The description is very apt for the game, and gives all the information you need, and for how long it takes.  It's exactly as it pictures: Florence is stuck in an endless loop of her life, and she finds Krish who starts breaking her out of that monotonous lifestyle.  However, it breaks from there.  It does describe that things are good for a while, but it doesn't romanticize the story from there.  There are fights, and it highlights that sometimes people fall out of love, and the game depicts the struggles of falling out of love with someone you've spent a great deal of your time and emotions with.  

It's one that hits very hard, and I think that this teaches a lot of valuable lessons.  Love is something both people work with, but it is okay if things don't work out.  It depicts that relationships are grisly and sometimes partners fight, but as long as you can come back and talk things out, you'll be alright.  It teaches that even when times get tough, you have to keep going, and sometimes you don't realize all the good memories until a later time.  This game gives so much, and it was a great experience from start to finish.  

From the music, to the interactive puzzles, to the implied meanings of the puzzles (like colored speech bubbles, or the sharper, jagged edges of the speech bubble as a conversation turns sour), it was a wonderful game from start to finish, and I would absolutely recommend it.

108928041.review:
This is not a game; this is a visual novel that can be completed in about 30 minutes. The drawings are cute and the music is pleasant. There are a lot of smart ways Florence uses "gameplay" mechanics to illustrate life experiences in an abstract manner, making it feel like an interactive art piece. It does it quite well, and really captures what it's like to grow into adulthood and be in a relationship.

Although the interactive components do add value to the experience, I think that Florence would have been just as strong of an experience within the pages of an illustrated book. I can only think of a couple of parts where the interactivity truly made the experience something more. The rest of it felt like I was playing a zen version of WarioWare Inc. And though Florence certainly feels accurate to life and does a great job of illustrating how it feels to navigate adulthood, it does not say anything particularly insightful about it.

Verdict: MODERATELY BAD

This is a really lovely game.  I will say this, take your time with it and GO IN BLIND, it makes the experience so much better, you won't regret it.  That being said.   It has a really cool mechanics that I've never seen before.  It's story is short, simple, but lovely and touching.  And that soundtrack,  I'll be honest, I had already forgot who wrote and preformed the songs, but they all did an amazingly wonderful job.  The classical tracks just fit the game so well.  I actually listened to the music before playing and it just made me want to play the game more.  Its beautiful and really well recorded.   It's a wonderful game with a good story of love, loss, and progression after hard times.  I have not got 100% on the game yet, but I would like to go back and get all the achievements I missed, but I do recommend going in not knowing what they are.  (Or even that they exist but to late)  as its really fun to just have one pop up for just playing the game.  Overall it's an amazing game all around.  The fact that it's all told through visuals and music (no dialogue is ever spoken and no text to tell you what to do, the bit that's there is only for context,)  makes it like your going through the story with the character, and making the events happen.  It's, again, really well done.  I will say it is a shame how fast you can go through, even if you take time take in each image.  It can feel like you just started an act and then your 3 more in.  Not to say it's not well paced, it's just you have to pace yourself as you go through.  If I have any advice for this game it's to not rush it.  Enjoy it.  It's good and deserves your time.  

I rate, 9.2 / 10

107329927.review:
I wouldn't even recommend this game on sale (which is when I got it at 67% off)

I am not against short games whatsoever if they deliver and pack a punch. I have played very short 1 hour ~ 2 hour long games that cost more than this does and I didn't regret many of them. The whimsical art style in Florence has a charm, but that's about where it ends for me. I am a very emotional person who loves to wallow in the occasional melancholic and cathartic game, book, and TV/film genres. I love a good cry or even anything that gets my emotional senses tingling. 

That being said, I've had more of an emotional reaction from a sad animal shelter commercial (you all know the one, cue Sarah McLachlan's sad advertisments) than this game. It's hardly interactive, which is fine, if it makes up for it elsewhere. The game being extremely short is already a downside, however, it could have made up for it in other areas. The art style is cute and whimsical but I wouldn't consider it to be making up for the lackluster gameplay or the shortness and lack of replayability with the game. If the story was very emotionally fueled and memorable, then I'd have thrown all criticisms of gameplay length, art style, and lack of interactive gameplay out of the window. However, the story was very mildly bittersweet and didn't move me much. This is coming from someone who will cry at sad songs, will cry through sad films, and has gone through several breakups that have left a scar. Trust me when I say that I am all about the bittersweet and cathartic human experience, but, this was a very mediocre and shallow representation of one.

Starting by doing your daily routine [i](eat - work - repeat)[/i] that feels usual and then you need to take a break [i](like go outside).[/i] Later on, you found someone that attracts your heart & hoping that you'll find that person again. And guess what? you found that person again and then having a chit-chat. Day after day, the bond between you & that person is getting stronger and 1 person will ask for a first date.

After couple of months of dating, you live together, doing things together, supporting each other, and genuinely make you & that person lives better. But sometimes bad things happen. Whether it's about life, work, mood, or fighting about something. Until you feels like you & that person aren't meant to be together. And then you broke up with that person & let that person go.

It might be hurts when someone that you loved so much broke up with you. You maybe couldn't forget but [b]YOU MAYBE COULD MOVE ON.[/b] [i]Memories between you & that person weren't always about bad things, there were also good things that happened even the sweetest one. The relationship between you & that person ends in heartbreak, but the moments, the memories, and a gesture of love led to a new life.[/i]

106707749.review:
Florence is more of a narrative driven game, about a girl that feels a little stuck. It's a relatable game and that's why for some of us it hurts so much. Her life is an endless routine of work, sleep, and spending too much time on social media to fill in the invisible yet present void. We've all been there. One day, she meets a cello player who makes her see the world in different colors. Florence is intimate, raw and personal.

The game lets you experience their relationship from the beginning, which makes it even more relatable especially when the puzzle dialogues are starting to appear. At first, the pieces seem more complex, there's many of them that you need to piece together, but as the story goes on, the pieces become easier and easier to piece together, since in a relationship at first you don't know what ground you're standing on and you need to carefully use your words until you learn about the things you have in common and it becomes much easier to talk to each other. 

The relationship shows the nice parts about it: flirting, helping each other grow and supporting one another's dreams; but also shows the not so pretty parts in relationships as well: fighting, taking what you have for granted because of the comfortable (maybe too comfortable) routine going on and sadly growing apart. The ending makes you understand that not every loss is a loss. That sometimes you need to go through a rough patch and even though at first it's hard and you're feeling lost, in time you find yourself and that passion you forgot you still carry with you.

Gameplay wise it consists of simple mini-puzzles that cannot be failed. The game presents itself as minimalistic but don't let that fool you. It is as impactful as its simple graphics. 

Honestly, if you are someone that has been through at least one real relationship, this game hits way too hard. You see the progress from the early stages until the last one, leaving you feeling nostalgic and craving for more. 

It is a bittersweet experience that in my opinion is worth the full price.

106562879.review:
[h1][b]ANÁLISIS DE [i]FLORENCE[/i]:[/b][/H1]

Florence es una mini-aventura desarrollada por Mountains y editada por Annapurna Interactive, que nos plantea una historia muy sencilla y cotidiana pero de una forma súper original y de una belleza artística muy elevada. A continuación entramos en detalles: 

[h1]Argumento:[/h1] (no hay spoilers)

Nos ponemos en el papel de Florence Yeoh, una chica de 25 años que se siente atrapada en un callejón sin salida. Una vida de rutina en un trabajo que no le llena, horas de sueño y mucho tiempo perdido en redes sociales. Un día conoce a alguien que quizás sea la persona que le haga darle la vuelta a su perspectiva de la vida.

Con esta temática tan sencilla y cotidiana se nos presenta esta mini-aventura en la que los personajes se expresan mediante gestos y bocadillos sin texto que nosotros mismos tendremos que interpretar, ya que no hay ni una sola palabra ni voces en todo el juego. Todo se sobreentiende bien a pesar de este detalle, ya que la emotividad de la música y su apartado artístico hace que todo sea muy fácil de interpretar. 

[h1]Jugabilidad:[/h1]

Florence también resulta un juego atípico en este apartado. Podría parecer una sencilla aventura gráfica, pero su control es distinto a lo habitual, quizás porque está pensado para jugarlo en dispositivos móviles. Con respecto a esta versión de ordenador solo tendremos que hacer uso del ratón, aunque según leo también se puede hacer uso del mando, algo que sinceramente no he probado. 

El manejo es bien sencillo: en ocasiones tendremos que darle solamente a siguiente, en otras arrastrar la pantalla como si de una web se tratase, en otras ocasiones tendremos que recoger piezas de puzle para completar los bocadillos que representan lo que se está diciendo en las conversaciones, hacer clic en algunos objetos, arrastrar otros y algún que otro pequeño y muy sencillo mini-puzle, nada que nos haga tener que pensar demasiado. 

[h1]Gráficos:[/h1]

No esperes grandes alardes en este apartado, Florence no busca sorprenderte por unos gráficos realistas y llenos de efectos. Su estética le imprime una personalidad única, muy original. Gráficos muy sencillos, trazos dibujados a mano de forma simple pero bien realizados que transmiten mucho con muy poco. 

[h1]Sonido:[/h1]

La banda sonora es simplemente perfecta. Nos acompaña de fondo durante todo el juego ya que no hay voces en los diálogos, pero la música está tan bien compuesta y elegida que se adapta a la perfección a la situación que se está representando en cada momento, transmitiendo los sentimientos de los personajes de la historia de una forma soberbia.

Os dejo mi lista de pros y contras:

[H1][b]PROS:[/b][/H1]

- Todo lo que transmite con tan poco

- Muy emotivo

- Artísticamente es precioso

- A pesar de su argumento cotidiano, el planteamiento es muy original

- La banda sonora es una auténtica maravilla

- Es muy sencillo sentirse identificado con la historia que nos está contando

- Se puede conseguir a buen precio en épocas de ofertas

- Tiene logros Steam

- Tiene cromos y artículos en la tienda de Steam

[H1][b]CONTRAS:[/b][/H1]

- Es muy corto, no llega ni a la hora de duración. Quizás te dure algo más si tienes que rejugar partes para conseguir algún logro que se te haya escapado

- Su precio base es elevado para lo que ofrece, solo lo compraría de oferta

- No es rejugable, hubiera estado bien la posibilidad de tomar decisiones distintas que tengan peso en la historia

[H1]Conclusión:[/h1]
------------------------

Una bonita experiencia de muy corta duración, que me ha encantado pero que sinceramente solo recomendaría en el caso de encontrarlo de oferta con una buena rebaja. Muy emotivo y bello, con mensaje, que podría ser de mucha ayuda anímica a personas que hayan pasado por una situación similar.

Si mi análisis te ha gustado o te ha servido de ayuda, agradecería que dejaras un voto positivo para que pueda llegar a más gente. También se agradecen los premios. ¡Gracias por leerme! No dudéis en dejar vuestros comentarios o dudas, responderé lo antes posible.

106272841.review:
[h1]#tinygamereviews[/h1]
Florence was a cool little game! Has all kinds of happy, sad, inspirational, and disheartening moments in an altogether relatable story.
[list]
    [*][b][u]Overall Score[/u][/b]: 5/5
[/list]
[hr][/hr]
[h1]Full Review[/h1]
[table]
    [tr]
        [td]Playability[/td]
        [td]4/5[/td]
        [td]Works amazingly with a controller, with a few small frustrations that come with moving a cursor using a controller.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Graphics[/td]
        [td]5/5[/td]
        [td]Charming art style.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Sound[/td]
        [td]5/5[/td]
        [td]Complements the story well - and the soundtrack comes free![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Story[/td]
        [td]4/5[/td]
        [td]Short, sweet, and gives all the right feels.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[i]Florence[/i] made me smile, laugh, sigh, get frustrated, tear up, and after all of that feel whole again in the span of maybe an hour or so. Playing the game was like watching a short film or reading a story - the playable segments were well-implemented and didn't make it seem like the story was pausing for useless interaction. Gameplay felt organic and purposeful.

For all its positives, [i]Florence[/i] is barely a "game." Much of it is a collection of scenes that you scroll through, or items that you pick up and drag to other spots on the screen. It's short enough that these mechanics don't get repetitive, but gameplay-wise, there's nothing terribly unique about it. [i]Florence[/i] is an [i]experience[/i] - a good one.

[table equalcells=1]
    [tr]
        [th]BEST[/th]
        [th]WORST[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]It's hard to decide when so many aspects of it are done so well! I think the best part overall, however, is that it's a story without words, which seemed to sharpen its emotional impact for me. As a literature buff, I'd consider that pretty high praise![/td]
        [td]Lack of replayability. Some of the choices and creations within the game persist with minor effects, but there are no alternate endings and the main plot points will always be the same.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table] 
[list]
    [*][b][u]In-Game Purchases[/u][/b]: None
    [*][b][u]Learning Curve[/u][/b]: Easy. Only small trouble might be moving the cursor with a controller, if you choose to use one (I did).
    [*][b][u]Replayability[/u][/b]: Low. There are a few differences in choices to be made, but the overall outcomes will always be the same.
    [*][b][u]Recommended Purchase Price[/u][/b]: ~$5
[/list]

106042823.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1] 
[b]Florence[/b] is a narrative-driven game, gameplay-wise it consists of simple mini-games with no possibility for failure.

[h1]Pros & Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros:[/b]
+ Beautiful hand-drawn graphics
+ Heart-warming story
+ Great soundtrack
+ Accessible to casual gamers

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Simple gameplay without any challenge
- Very short (around 40 minutes on first playthrough)

[h1]Story[/h1]
It’s hard to talk about the story without spoiling it, so I'll only give it one sentence. The game follows a girl stuck in a boring job with no friends and no love, but with a dream for a better life. It’s a slice of life kind of story, there aren’t any unexpected twists, strange mysteries or high stakes. Just some of the most heartwarming and heartbreaking moments of a girl’s life. The story is very relatable and will definitely leave an emotional impact on you. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The game consists of simple mini-games, they don’t require any special skills and can be easily completed by someone who hasn’t played videogames before. Simple as it is, it doesn’t get boring and the mini-games themselves are so masterfully integrated into the narrative, so you can’t imagine [b]Florence[/b] being anything other than a game. Every gameplay mechanic tries to convey some emotion, best example of this would be the jigsaw puzzle that appears during conversations and gets easier and easier with each level as your character gets more familiar and chattier with her friend. 

[h1]Graphics & Audio[/h1]
It looks like a hand-drawn comic with a lot of love put into it. It’s not very detailed and character faces look very simple. But it’s very emotional, it seems like every detail was put in its’ place for story-related reasons and not just for the good picture. The music is perfect. It sets the tone of the game and every melody hits you right in the feels. Some of the tracks will probably stay in your head long after you finished the game.

[h1]Performance[/h1]
Specs: Intel Core i5-7300HQ, 12GB RAM, NVIDIA GTX 1050 4GB.

It runs perfectly in 1080p at 60 FPS. There are no technical issues whatsoever.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
While it is a short game with simple graphics, almost no gameplay and a story you’ve heard a thousand times before, you can’t just pass it by. It’s a small game, that will evoke more emotions in you in the span of 30 minutes than a complex big budget game will in 10 hours.

105098072.review:
It pains me to give Florence a negative review, but even with the most generously broadened definition of the term I must judge it for what it presents itself as: a video game on Steam.

While the art style is remarkably cute and the music is consistently fluttery and pleasant throughout the experience, Florence fails to generate the feeling of excitement or engrossment that I would generally expect from a game. It is naught but an interactive flipbook, where the only interactive part lies in moving pieces around and figuring out where to click or scroll next and your choices don't seem to matter other than objects reappearing minutes later in the playthrough.

The story tugs at your heart strings a little, but it's mundane and predictable; it may be intentionally so, but the narrative fails to elevate it and the artistic bells & whistles alone aren't enough to make the 30 minutes necessary to complete it (barring achievements) memorable.

Perhaps Florence would be better suited on Itch.io at a lower asking price and the "pay what you want" format; here, I cannot recommend it.

105041834.review:
Even at full-price, this costs almost less than a greeting card. You'd be lucky to get an hour out of it, and I struggle to see much replay-value in here. So, it is sort of typical of the Annapurna library -- not a very deep game, but a deeply artistic and music presentation of a story that cuts deep.  Lots of 'deep' in that last sentence...

I hesitate to say this game is 'beautiful' because I feel I use that too much, but this is just [i]beautiful[/i]. It's is mostly a short story about love found and love lost, but it is told so expertly and hits incredibly hard.  There should be some kind of award for the narrative tricks this game plays.  I don't want to spoil them, but one of the game's few recurring mechanics is super-effective at capturing concepts like, "her words became easier, and the conversation flowed," and "the conversation became more pointed, cutting with sharp edges."

To say much more would ruin the story, and I really think you should experience it yourself. It won't take much time, won't take much money, and might stick with you for a lot longer than you'd expect.

A very cool, albeit short game telling the story of the main character Florence.
Flora is an ambitious girl of 20 years who has lost the taste of life, and suddenly for a moment she meets Chris.
Chris is a cellist who dreams of a career as a musician and great fame, and Flora does not mind.
This game was created to tell you that everything can change dramatically in life and you should not give up after that and lose yourself...

8.5 out of 10

[code]Puedes ver más reseñas como esta en la mentoría [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34129733/][u]PIXEL 404[/u][/url][/code]

[h1]Como la vida misma[/h1]

Florence es un juego bastante difícil de catalogar, y mucho menos decir si es un juego recomendable o no. Es uno de esos títulos en los que desearías que hubiera un botón intermedio para valorarlo.

El juego, como podrás ver en la tienda, tiene un ”muy positivos”, pero eso no significa, ni de lejos, que sea muy bueno. Simplemente es un juego simpático y agradable que no te llevará más de una hora terminar. De hecho, llamarlo “juego” me parece pasarse un poco. Más bien es una experiencia interactiva de perfil bajo donde nos cuentan una historia. Una historia bastante normalita por otra parte. 

Es decir, si lees algunas reseñas, podrás ver cosas como “una historia increíble”, o “una historia muy hermosa”, etc… Bueno, después de haber jugado al juego y haber visto lo que ofrece, el único motivo lógico que se me ocurre para que alguien diga eso es que no ha tenido una pareja en su vida. Que, por lo que veo, según las reseñas, son muchos. Legión, mas bien.

El juego no te cuenta una “historia increíble”, ni una historia “muy hermosa”. Lo que hace es contarte una historia de amor entre dos personas que se conocen, y punto. ¿Es bonito? Hombre, hablamos del amor, pero no es especialmente buena la historia. Es decir, si ya has vivido algo así alguna vez en tu vida pues te sonará a algo ya visto y así pues pierde gracia la cosa. A buen seguro la mayoría de la gente tiene mejores historias personales que contar sobre el amor que la que se cuenta en Florence.

Es decir, el juego cuenta una historia de enamoramiento, pero todo es muy normal, no es una historia estrambótica, ni interesante porque te sorprenda ni nada por el estilo. Es una historia de relación de pareja como la que se da millones de veces al día en este mundo.

Por otra parte, el juego ofrece, aparte de su historia, pequeñas pinceladas a modo de minijuegos. Son entretenidos en su mayor parte, y graciosos en algunas otras. No es que aporten demasiado, pero se agradece. De hecho, será la mayor interacción que tendremos en la paupérrima hora que dura el juego.

En definitiva, Florence es un juego atípico, muy muy corto, que no ofrece nada no vivido a quien haya vivido, pero que se deja disfrutar durante breves instantes. Lo recomendaría para bundle o rebajado en su máxima expresión, pero poco más. No creo que merezca la pena hacer una mayor inversión debido a su escasísima duración y a lo poco que aporta realmente.

"Short and sweet" is the perfect way to describe this game. Florence is about an hour long, and it's sort of like a virtual comic with some minigames spliced in here and there. The story is mainly slice of life, and it shows us the way we can feel stuck in a rut in adulthood, and how we can find the spark that makes life fun again.

The gameplay likely won't blow you away, but the story and art is the main draw here. It tells it's story with visuals and very little words, in an easy to understand way. It's a good, short form game that's worth checking out, especially if you're an artist at heart.

103306430.review:
Florence (Florencia, como nombre femenino), es una historia interactiva del 13 de Febrero del 2020.
Somos Florencia Yeoh, de 25 años, con una vida rutinaria, común y corriente, hasta que conocemos a Krish, un violonchelista que vemos en el parque. El juego cuenta nuestra historia a través de seis actos, divididos en veinte breves capítulos, y presenta un pequeño diálogo escrito, y pequeños rompecabezas, utilizados para reforzar piezas de nuestra vida, a medida que avanza la historia.
El juego se desarrolla de forma lineal, lo que requiere nuestra participación en forma de minijuegos cortos que ayudan a imitar o revelar los pensamientos y acciones de Florence. Los desarrolladores hicieron del juego una experiencia lineal desde el principio del proceso debido a la preocupación de que las personas con más experiencia en la vida tomaran las decisiones "correctas" y evitaran la moraleja del juego…
En cuanto a música (sustitutiva del dialogo), el equipo decidió utilizar el violonchelo representando a Krish mientras que el piano sigue a Florence.

103298827.review: I think it's especially important to note how much one can tell with so little. It's amazing how simple, yet so profound the story is, and the way the game conveys emotion and dialogue without the use of actual words is amazing. I never knew it was possible to convey so much heart with mere puzzle pieces. It also goes without saying that both the art direction and musical composition are stellar. Every note is so in-tune with what was happening on screen, and the story as a whole left me quite gutted upon first play. However, the more I thought about it, the more I began to like how the story ended. I think that the impact of the game would have been much less if the ending was anything other than bittersweet. Everyone who worked on this did an amazing job.

101973784.review:
I want to start off by saying that I was really excited to play this game. I knew the type of game it was going into it, and I knew it had very little "gameplay" and was quite short. I don't mind any of these things, in fact some of my favorite games are very similar in these aspects. Unfortunately Florence just left me kind of underwhelmed. It's not a bad game, in fact I think if you're into these kinds of games that you'll enjoy it. I just didn't enjoy it nearly as much as I thought I would after hearing all the praise this game has gotten. It has some very interesting, unique, and well executed ideas in terms of what you can do with simply clicking and dragging things on screen, and the way the game is able to turn simple actions into representing the emotions of the characters is quite remarkable to be honest. The art style and music are both beautifully done and add a lot to the game. They both change accurately to the situation and help make this experience what it is. Sadly though, what is perhaps the most important part of these types of games, the story, is where the game fell short for me. 

The entire game takes probably 35-40 minutes to play through, not even half of most movies. The game just isn't long enough to build up the relationship between the characters to make anything it does really feel anything. Most of the emotions I felt playing this game came more from the artwork and soundtrack then my actual feelings towards the characters. There just isn't enough time to really build the bond between the characters and everything that happens between them is very cookie cutter and predictable. It's all honestly just kind of predictable. Despite the stories flaws, if you can get it on sale for the $3 asking price it normally goes down to and are usually a fan of these types of games, then I think there's still enough that's done right to make it worth your time. It's just a shame because if they had just fleshed things out a little more, this game truly could've been close to a masterpiece. For more reviews visit my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/40795588/] curator page. [/url]

101941649.review: Wonderful. It has a very simple story, but gets the job done right by telling you not to lose hope, even in your darkest days.

101928851.review:
Such a gripping experience!
The Story revolves around Florence Yeoh, a normal 25 year old women who goes about their day-to-day life, until she meets a busker named Krish who will change up her perceptions on life and herself. The characters in this game are well developed enough for the player to understand the type of individuals they are and witness the way that they will grow throughout the game. The story itself is fantastically told. Everything from gameplay, to sound to visuals all contribute and blend perfectly to portray such an amazing journey. 
The Settings in this game add another layer of characterisation and depth to Florence as they themselves tell their own story and give more details and ideas for the player to branch upon.
Visually, this game looks stunning. The artstyle is done in this pencil drawing/scrapbook style which fits the tone perfectly. Even the way colour is used in the game is great as it becomes a great indicator of the tone/emotions that are taking place in a certain moment. 
Sound and audio again just add even more layers to the games story telling and makes this experience more immersive. The OST with its grand violins and orchestral pieces help greatly with the emotions that are being portrayed in a certain scene and the audio choices for when the player is interacting is just so satisfying. 
In terms of gameplay, there isn't a lot here. You will be mainly be using your mouse to click or drag things that are key for a particular moment. While that might not sound engaging, the way the developers work around this and the things that you do interact with really make you feel that you are progressing and contributing to the story. The only thing i wish the game had was a longer run time just because i loved every bit of this game!
Overall, Florence is a brilliant story-rich game that had me hooked from start to finish and i would recommend this to anyone wanting to be sucked up by an amazing narrative of becoming ones true self.

101330307.review:
Gorgeous. This game is so beautifully made; it captures all of the feelings of the time in one's life it explores: new love, heartbreak, ambition and new beginnings.

It's essentially an interactive novel, and yet each section utilises play mechanics that brilliantly mirror the action. When Florence falls off her bike, the player has to adjust the image as she regains her senses. When she goes on a first date, a conversation-shaped puzzle becomes increasingly easy to solve. It sounds simple, but it sidesteps that awkward balance so many VNs struggle to find between being a game and being a story with buttons. Florence's playstyle fits the story perfectly.
 
Artistically, it's flawless. The art style and soundtrack are so inviting; the music will be on loop in your house for days to come, bringing all the feels back both good and bad. While it's a small game from an indie dev, it feels and looks polished. Like Moebius-inspired platformer Gris, the colour palette is an important part of how Florence tells its story. As it progresses, colour becomes a currency that is gained and lost as the title character experiences the highs and lows of their journey.

As an Australian gamer, I very much appreciated this accurate portrayal of our culture: the suburban, art-filled world of Melbourne (which reminded me of another favourite, Necrobarista (worth your time)) that sat in contrast to the garish, larrikin stereotypes that so often plague our representation. Florence feels sophisticated, and it celebrates the multiculturalism that Australia should be so proud of.

Play it. Buy it and play it over and over again. Revisit it when you're happy, or when you're sad. And as it is an easy game to play, share it with people who might not normally play games. Florence is a gift. Treat yourself.

Rating: 10 wistful cello solos out of 10. Perfection.

100278381.review:
El juego es un retrato : intimo, emotivo y frustrante que todos hemos experimentado, enamorarse es genial!, pero a veces la realidad es que todas las relaciones no están destinadas a durar, puede parecer una historia de amor el juego, pero es mucho más que eso. Es una evocación de la belleza, la tristeza y la esperanza que proviene de cualquier conexión humana que hacemos en nuestras vidas.
Cuenta la historia de florence Yeoh, de 25 años, envuelta en una rutina mundana, apaga la alarma del reloj antes de despertarse, se levanta de la cama, se lava los dientes, desayuna sola, va al trabajo, navegar sin pensar en las redes sociales, una vida aburrida en su trabajo o suele conversar con su preocupada madre por teléfono, hasta que un día encuentra a Krish, un indio australiano con un sueño enterrado de convertirse en un violonchelista profesional.
después de una serie de citas, los dos terminan comenzando una relación y la historia se desarrolla a partir de ahí.
El juego es corto, aproximadamente 1 hora, pero brinda una experiencia de calidad basada en la narración auténticamente maravillosa ,basada en una especie de novela gráfica interactiva donde a menudo debes completar tareas para poder avanzar. El juego se divide por capítulos, un buen trabajo es la conversación entre florence y krish a medida que se descubren y establecen una relación, no hay palabras, sino más bien rompecabezas de forma simple que se utilizan para construir burbujas de discurso. La música es hermosa y juega un papel importante para evocar ritmos emocionales encajando con el ambiente relativamente relajado y agradable del juego.
En Fin...Florence es lindo mezcla una emoción de los sueños y el nuevo amor con las inevitables presiones externas, la honestidad y la sabiduría que viene con la edad.

99461925.review: "Florence" is a short indie game with a lot of heart. I was expecting something more along the lines of a visual novel, but I love how the devs made subtle yet impactful changes that showed the creativity and character in this story. The playthrough is simple, and while it's nothing groundbreaking, and you complete easy, routine tasks like solving math equations or unpacking items or putting together puzzle pieces, it works to highlight the themes of the story, and the interactive aspects make it feel more personal. I think the strongest aspect is the original soundtrack, with moving piano and strings. There isn't much dialogue in this game, and though I was at first taken aback that the player doesn't get to hear the conversations, with little written text, it became clear that the expressions show enough emotion, as well as the accompanying music. The significance of the puzzle pieces stands out especially, noting how the pieces become more congruent, becoming closer to one, and then on the other spectrum, become jagged to express the lack of unity and connection. Basically, "Florence" shines in its illustrations and storyboard, providing the player with plenty of depth into the themes of self-discovery, loss, and finding a place in this world. It's beautifully and delicately told, and though under an hour, completely worth it. You can tell the devs care about their work in the concept and character art that is accessible to the player, and I love when that care comes through to the player.
